center for strategic and international studies csis has just released safeguarding our subsea cables  a report looking at how to safeguard cyber infrastructure amid great power competition a few key points 

1 95 of international data moves on undersea fibre optic cables satellite communications like starlink are advancing rapidly but is there is no substitute to undersea cables to maintain global communication as we know it globally critical infrastructure and particularly important for an island continent like australia 

2 98 of cables are manufactured and installed by four private firms in 2021 the us company subcom french firm alcatel submarine networks asn and japanese firm nippon electric company nec collectively held an 87 market share chinas hmn technologies held another 11 repair and maintenance of this network during competition and conflict will depend on the private sector

3 attacking undersea cables are going to feature heavily as we see escalated competition and certainly in combat in 2023 two submarine cables that supply internet to taiwans matsu islands were cut plunging its 14000 residents into digital isolation for six weeks australia must be ready to respond to cables being cut and build resilience against digital isolation



 via australian communications and media authority

post_text:
rwe and the oyster restoration company have completed a groundbreaking sixmonth feasibility study showing that largescale native oyster reef restoration is possible at offshore wind farms in the north sea 

this project delivers a practical scalable blueprintfrom substrate testing and engineering to monitoring frameworksfor netpositive biodiversity gains a major step in enhancing marine ecosystems alongside renewable energy development

more info
one_sentence_description: RWE is a German energy company that focuses on renewable energy development and offshore wind farm projects.
project_summary: RWE and The Oyster Restoration Company have completed a six-month feasibility study on large-scale native oyster reef restoration at offshore wind farms in the North Sea, delivering a practical and scalable blueprint for net positive biodiversity gains.
cosma_opportunity:
COSMA could contribute to the project by providing AUV (Autonomous Underwater Vehicle) services for various survey needs, such as:

1. UXO detection: Utilizing magnetometers onboard the AUVs to detect Unexploded Ordnance (UXO), ensuring the safety of the restoration activities and personnel.

2. Bathymetry mapping: Employing sonar and multibeam echosounders to create high-resolution maps of the seabed, aiding in route planning and clearance, as well as foundation inspection.

3. Seabed characterization: Conducting sub-bottom profiling to gather information about the physical properties of the seabed, which is essential for substrate testing and engineering purposes.

4. Cable route mapping: Using AUVs equipped with side-scan sonar to map cable routes, helping in the planning and installation process of power cables related to the offshore wind farms.

5. Environmental baseline surveys: Performing environmental surveys to establish a reference point for monitoring changes in marine ecosystems during and after the oyster reef restoration project, contributing to the overall goal of enhancing marine biodiversity alongside renewable energy development.
ideal_contact: Contact the RWE team responsible for the Oyster Restoration Project in the North Sea. Reason for contacting is to discuss potential collaborations, partnerships or investments related to large-scale native oyster reef restoration at offshore wind farms.
recommended_action: Initiate a follow-up meeting or conversation with the RWE team to explore opportunities and further details about their feasibility study and blueprint for net positive biodiversity gains.
reasoning: The high scores in Relevance, Stage, and Company indicate that this project is significant, well-developed, and relevant to your interests. A proactive approach will allow you to capitalize on the potential benefits of collaborating with RWE on this promising initiative.

a massive thank you to ashley hunn from north star for inviting myself and tgs colleagues onboard the grampian tweed on a very windy friday 7th feb prior to her final commissioning checks which were carried out on the sunday it was so windy we nearly lost our hard hats multiple times

this impressive vessel was docked at the brand new leef facility within associated british ports lowestoft and is designed to support equinor sse renewables and vrgrnn with the om activities for the dogger bank offshore wind farm throughout the next few years with a potential of up to 60 offshore workers onboard at a time

some observations from our market research team 
 vessel is using the latest technology including two tunnel bow thrusters
 incredibly stable and quiet dp system and blade based props for better manoeuvrability
 hybrid with large battery storage on board the vessel has 4 generators aiming to only ever use two generators and supplement peaks in power demand from the batteries
 the ship can last 30 mins on the batteries alone
 has multiple vacant spaces within the hullnear engine facilities this enable to the vessel to add additional storagefuel tanks making it able to use more than one fuel type in the future
 utilises themotion compensation system for the w2w gangway

full vessel specs can be found on our 4c offshore dashboard

post_text:
chiles government is investigating the idea of linking chile to antarctica via a subsea cable this is part of a larger initiative to make chile a major telecom and data center hub its government is partnering with google on the humboldt cable that will connect australia to chile with branching units to important pacific island chains like french polynesia and fiji pioneer consulting a very well known and respected subsea cable design company based in new jersey will do the feasibility study antarctica has a number of research stations including americas national science foundations mcmurdo facility web cam photo of the station below as of 1130 am cet here is a link to a relevant article 

these research sites definitely need more bandwidth than they currently get via geostationary satellite providers and starlinks leo service not clear if they are willing to pay enough to justify building the proposed antarctic cable a big concern is ice scouring this is where icebergs scrape the bottom of the continental shelf plowing the ocean floor and potentially destroying any cables buried there it is not just an academic possibility ice scouring severed quintillions alaska cable in 2023 and again on january 24 2025 repairs are not routine the expected time to repair the latest damage is september of 2025 average mean time to repair is six to nine months i suspect it is simply too expensive to hire an icebreaker during the extreme winter conditions a good maintenance contract for the chiletoantarctica cable would be very expensive as the likelihood of ice scouring is high along the antarctica continental shelf and mcmurdo is a long way from any major south american port

consequently i overflow with skepticism about these projects because cable construction would be very expensive with very deep burial required in antarcticas coastal waters furthermore outages would be frequent and long lasting and clients are not typically charged for service during force majeure outages i doubt there exist price points that generate enough customer interest to lease capacity and yet generate enough revenue to justify the project even if chiles government provides grants i think what is likely to happen is that these research stations will use amazons 1 gig leo service when it becomes available in the near future there will be soon high capacity leo service available as opposed to starlinks current scrawny offerings
 plus

project_summary: Blue Water Shipping is conducting feasibility studies for a major offshore wind farm project in the UK, focusing on port capabilities, load assessments, laydown areas, infrastructure readiness, and strategic route analysis.
cosma_opportunity:
COSMA could potentially contribute to the project by providing advanced Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) services for various survey needs. Here's a breakdown of how our capabilities align with the possible survey needs mentioned:

1. UXO detection: Utilizing magnetometers onboard our AUVs, we can assist in detecting Unexploded Ordnance (UXO) during the seabed characterization phase.

2. Bathymetry mapping: Our AUVs equipped with sonar and multibeam echosounders can accurately map the seafloor topography for bathymetric surveys, aiding in route planning and clearance.

3. Route planning and clearance: By combining bathymetric data with sub-bottom profiler information, COSMA's AUVs can help identify potential hazards and optimize routes for offshore energy operations.

4. Foundation inspection: Our AUVs can be equipped with cameras and other sensors to inspect the condition of foundation structures underwater, ensuring their integrity during the construction phase.

5. Cable route mapping: Using side-scan sonar technology, our AUVs can map the seabed for cable routes, helping in the planning and installation process of power cables for the offshore wind farm.

6. Seabed characterization: By collecting detailed data on the seabed composition, COSMA's AUVs can help characterize the seabed, which is crucial for understanding the environmental conditions and selecting appropriate foundation types.

7. Environmental baseline surveys: Our AUVs can collect water quality samples, measure temperature, salinity, and other parameters to establish an environmental baseline for the project area, ensuring compliance with regulations and minimizing potential impacts on marine life.

By leveraging our advanced AUV technology and expertise in underwater survey operations, Blue Water Shipping could benefit from smarter, more efficient solutions during their feasibility studies and subsequent offshore energy operations.

post_text:
ztt powers the worlds largest singleunit floating wind turbine  mingyang tiancheng

on december 11 2024 the worlds largest singleunit floating wind turbine the 166mw mingyang tiancheng officially connected to the grid marking a monumental achievement in renewable energy ztt was entrusted with the projects most critical component the design delivery construction and installation of all dynamic submarine cables and accessories ztts technical expertise ensured the seamless grid connection and reliable power generation of this groundbreaking floating wind platform

the mingyang tiancheng features a revolutionary v configuration and a turbine foundation capable of significant offset and 360 rotation challenging traditional submarine cable design and installation practices ztt conducted comprehensive simulation analyses to address these complexities and developed a bespoke 35kv dynamic submarine cable system this included a meticulously optimized laying plan to accommodate the unique movement of the dynamic foundation

the projects execution showcased ztts unparalleled technical competency the yuanwei construction team deployed dynamic positioning dp diving systems rov remotely operated vehicle underwater robots and advanced preinstallation techniques for accessories these innovations enabled efficient and precise submarine cable installation within a narrow operational window following completion the system faced its ultimate test when super typhoon yagi struck the region the cables remained intact and their line shape and performance exceeded expectations affirming ztts engineering excellence

this achievement testifies to ztts position at the forefront of dynamic submarine cable technology it demonstrates the companys readiness to meet and exceed the demands of even more challenging global projects cementing its reputation as a trusted leader in marine energy solutions

with over ten global demonstration projects in marine energy development and dynamic submarine cable applications ztt continues to set benchmarks in the floating wind power industry by combining innovation and precision the company is driving advancements in deepsea largescale floating offshore wind power solutions supporting the global transition to sustainable energy

european commission the european commissions welcome of the joint statement on the security and resilience of undersea cables at the un general assembly is a necessary step but lets not fool ourselvesthis is just the beginning submarine cables are the backbone of global connectivity yet they remain vulnerable to a wide range of threats from hacking to unauthorized surveillance the principles outlinedchoosing lowrisk providers enhancing cybersecurity and ensuring route diversityare progress but theyre far from foolproof

sixteen years ago i was part of a telecommunications cable repair with pepepolymers and that cable is still operational today but the fact that were endorsing such statements now should make us question whether weve been too complacent about these critical infrastructures for too long the truth is security cant be an afterthoughtit must be the foundation otherwise were just patching holes in a sinking ship

building the digital base africas datacentre boom

africas live datacentre footprint will triple by 2027 will your users sit within a 50ms latency zone

training a modern largelanguage model takes 10plus  more compute than it did just five years ago yet africa still hosts well under 2 of the worlds datacentre power that picture is changing fast more than thirty tier iiiplus facilities backed by teraco equinix digital realties open access dc and national telcos have been deployed with larger facilities slated to go live by 2027 clustering around johannesburg lagos nairobi and cairo

so what
compute is the bedrock of ai where racks gpus and edge nodes land determines where startups can train models where banks can clear realtime payments and how fast rural telehealth apps load if africa misses this buildout window it becomes more difficult to scale and grow this market if it seizes it there is substantial upside both directly from the ai growth potential and additional adjacencies that the infrastructure unlocks

impact on africa
cheaper lowerlatency cloud lets founders prototype locally instead of roundtripping to europe greenenergy datafarms solar  battery  liquid cooling turn africas sunlight into an esg edge attracting global ai workloads distributed edge clusters near universities and digital campuses keep research and bigdata training at home feeding the local talent pipeline

what must be done
 greenpower ppas  secure longterm renewable power contracts so hyperscalers can meet esg targets and keep energy costs affordable and predictable
 tax holidays  fasttrack permits  zero import duty on chillers ups and gpus as well as related renewable energy equipment and ancillary equipment singlewindow approvals that cut build timelines from 24 months to 12

south china sea  strategic logistics hub  agila subic shipyard in subic bay  3 clips  1 cerberus expands in the philippines to invest another p15 billion  manila philippines  new yorkbased private equity giant cerberus capital management is looking to invest an additional 250 million p15 billion in shipyard improvement and key infrastructure projects in the philippines
  in a statement on friday the office of the special assistant to the president for investment and economic affairs of the philippines said cerberus investment covers the upgrading of its agila subic shipyard in subic bay and undertaking of logistics energy and transport infrastructure projects over the next 12 months
 currently the shipyard hosts major tenants including global shipbuilder hd hyundai heavy industries subsea fiber optic data cables manufacturer subcom publicly listed logistics firm v2x and the philippine navy which operates a portion of the facility
 according to cerberus hd hyundai heavy industries will commence shipbuilding operations in the fourth quarter of this year from the original schedule of january 2026
 special assistant to the president for investment and economic affairs frederick go said cerberus projects in the pipeline would generate thousands of jobs open new avenues for regional growth and secure the countrys position as a key logistics hub in southeast asia


2 us to assist in building new naval pier at subic bay  he us will support manilas plan to build a new naval pier at a philippine naval base in subic bay
 a 15meter by 155meter finger pier is set to be constructed at naval operating base subic homeport of the philippine navys patrol vessels and frigates according to the contract the planning for the pier is under foreign military financing for the armed forces of the philippines and will be in support of naval sea systems commands international fleet support program office known as pms 326 construction of the pier itself will be conducted by the subic drydock corporation a philippine company

3 south koreas hyundai heavy industries to invest in the philippines subic shipyard  hyundai heavy industries acting on behalf of parent company hd korea shipbuilding and offshore engineering will use the facility for the manufacture of offshore wind power substructures and the expansion of its maintenance repair and overhaul mro business

post_text:
top management cases  fpso installation field connection  startup
1 installation planning  execution
mooring system installation
prelay anchors chains suction piles or torpedo anchors
requires precise marine spread coordination tugs barges rovs
turret or spread mooring connection
highrisk activity with tight weather windows
ensure precise alignment with preinstalled mooring lines
riser  umbilical installation
connection of dynamic risers and umbilicals from seabed to fpso
flow assurance and bending radius control critical
2 offshore logistics  marine coordination
tug tow and positioning operations
fpso towing to site and dynamic positioning
requires marine assurance towing analysis and weather forecast alignment
simops simultaneous operations management
overlap of hookup commissioning marine operations and hsecritical activities
must have clear simops matrix ptw control and emergency response plans
3 hse management in offshore phase
offshore work involves highrisk lifting diving and vessel operations
enforce strict permittowork ptw and emergency evacuation plans
must comply with imca imo ism and client hse standards
4 subsea tiein to wells and infrastructure
well jumpers plets and manifold connection
requires rovs divers or remote systems
leak testing pressure testing and chemical line flushing needed
well integrity and functional testing
verify isolation scssv operation and hydraulic functionality
interface with well operations and reservoir management teams
5 commissioning  startup readiness
mechanical completion  punch clearance
confirm system readiness via punch lists abc categories
use systems like icaps opercom or hexagon commissioning tools
prestartup safety review pssr
ensure all systems are safe and complete for first hydrocarbons
validate esd fg emergency shutdown flare and critical alarms
cold  hot commissioning
cold without hydrocarbons  flushing calibration function testing
hot with hydrocarbons  first oil rampup and process tuning
6 first oil operations
controlled flow from first wells
gradual increase of production while monitoring temperature pressure flow and separation performance
monitor flare process stability and safety systems live
7 performance testing  handover
72hour or 30day performance test as per contract
system reliability uptime and throughput validated
handover to operations team for steadystate production
 summary
installation field connection and startup of an fpso are highrisk multidisciplinary phases requiring precision in marine operations commissioning subsea tieins hse and coordination with drilling and production teams

post_text:
jordanian and egyptian ministers inspect lng fsru at sheikh sabah port to advance regional gas cooperation

shipping arabia august 7 2025  jordans minister of energy dr saleh kharabsheh and egypts minister of petroleum eng karim badawi visited the floating storage and regasification unit fsru energos force at sheikh sabah lng port in aqaba following the vessels arrival last friday chartered by the egyptian natural gas holding company egas the fsru is set to begin operations in the coming days as part of a strategic initiative to bolster regional energy integration

the visit aimed to assess the vessels readiness for connection to the arab gas pipeline and to oversee final preparations before the start of regasification operations a second vessel carrying operational testing equipment is expected to arrive tomorrow to facilitate commissioning activities

dr kharabsheh emphasized that the vessel with a storage capacity of 3600 million cubic feet and a sendout rate of 750 million cubic feet per day plays a key role in strengthening jordans energy security he highlighted that the initiative aligns with the national strategy to diversify gas sources and improve system flexibility during peak demand or emergency scenarios the fsru will be berthed at the aqaba lng terminal under a lease agreement between nepco and the aqaba development corporation adc following a cooperation framework with egas

minister badawi noted that the vessel serves as a joint solution for emergency gas supply between jordan and egypt reflecting the depth of bilateral cooperation and the importance of shared infrastructure in responding to regional energy needs

shadi ramzi almajali chairman of the aqaba special economic zone authority aseza welcomed the deployment as a milestone in aqabas development as a regional energy hub he stressed that the project reinforces the kingdoms gas supply capacity while supporting local investment and job creation

the energos force deployment follows a january 2024 agreement between jordan and egypt enabling the use of egyptian lng infrastructure to support jordans energy system a subsequent arrangement between nepco and egas granted operational flexibility at sheikh sabah port reducing idle time and enhancing cost efficiency

this project marks a significant step in arab energy collaboration laying the groundwork for longterm infrastructure development it also supports ongoing efforts to establish an onshore regasification facility in aqaba further reinforcing the regions role in meeting future energy demands

source aqaba special economic zone authority aseza

post_text:
geotechnical drilling at sea involves studying the soil and rocks beneath the seabed to assess their mechanical physical and chemical properties this information is crucial for designing and implementing marine projects such as bridges oil platforms submarine cables and gas pipelines

 steps of geotechnical drilling at sea

1 site selection the location is chosen based on project requirements and preliminary studies
2 collecting surface data devices like sonar and surface surveys are used to gather initial data on the seabed topography
3 positioning the marine drill the marine drill is placed over the designated site using dynamic positioning or mooring systems
4 drilling and sampling drilling starts using a rotary drill samples of soil and rock are taken at various depths
5 onsite testing includes tests like the standard penetration test spt and cone penetration test cpt
6 sample analysis samples are sent to a laboratory for detailed analysis of their properties

 operating marine drills

 essential equipment

1 marine drill rig a specialized platform equipped with drilling devices
2 drilling tools including drills pipes and sampling tools
3 stabilization equipment to maintain platform stability during drilling
4 measuring devices for measuring pressure depth and drilling speed

 operating steps

1 preparing equipment inspecting and ensuring the readiness of equipment
2 transporting to site moving the marine drill rig to the selected site
3 stabilization securing the drill rig at the site using mooring or dynamic positioning systems
4 starting drilling operating the drill and beginning drilling to the required depths
5 sampling periodically extracting samples and performing initial analysis
6 onsite testing conducting necessary tests during drilling
7 concluding operations after collecting the required data finishing the drilling and retrieving the equipment

 challenges

1 environmental conditions such as waves and marine currents
2 equipment the need for specialized equipment suitable for marine environments
3 safety ensuring the safety of workers and equipment

geotechnical drilling at sea requires high technical expertise and knowledge to ensure accurate and reliable data collection to meet the needs of various marine projects

us aims to ban chinese technology in undersea telecommunications cables



the federal communications commission said on wednesday it plans to adopt rules to bar companies from connecting undersea submarine communication cables to the united states that include chinese technology or equipment

we have seen submarine cable infrastructure threatened in recent years by foreign adversaries like china fcc chair brendan carr said in a statement we are therefore taking action here to guard our submarine cables against foreign adversary ownership and access as well as cyber and physical threats

the us has broad data security concerns about the network of more than 400 subsea cables that handle 99 of international internet traffic

the fcc last year said it was considering new rules governing undersea internet cables in the face of growing security concerns as part of a review of regulations on the links that handle nearly all the worlds online traffic the fcc said it was considering barring the use of equipment or services in those undersea cable facilities from companies on an fcc list of companies deemed to pose threats to us national security including huawei zte  opens new tab  opens new tab china telecom and china mobile  opens new tab

hydrography is the unsung hero of offshore projects laying the foundation for safe efficient and sustainable operations without it many offshore activities would be impossible or unsafe

 why hydrography matters

1 safe navigation hydrographic surveys create accurate seafloor maps ensuring vessels and equipment avoid hazards
2 foundation for infrastructure offshore platforms pipelines and wind farms rely on precise seabed data for proper installation and stability
3 environmental protection hydrographic surveys help assess and mitigate the environmental impact of offshore activities
4 disaster prevention by identifying seabed hazards and geological risks hydrography plays a critical role in preventing accidents

 applications in action

 site selection for offshore wind farms and oil platforms
 route planning for submarine cables and pipelines
 monitoring sediment movement and coastal erosion
 supporting marine construction projects with detailed seafloor data

 hydrography the backbone of offshore success

post_text:
i visited the beatrice offshore wind farm om base yesterday accompanying other staff from sse renewables the marine directorate naturescot and others from the moray firth regional advisory group sadly the weather didnt allow for a boat trip out to the turbines but we did get a tour of the ctv and a visit to the ssemicrosoftavanade ai puffin monitoring cameras

it was good to hear about the beatrice year 2 postconstruction ornithology monitoring work conducted by mcarthur green which looked at seabird displacement effects of the windfarm a key strength of the method developed for this analysis is that it does not rely on betweenyear comparisons which helps untangle normal yeartoyear variations from windfarm effects

the results showed that guillemot razorbill puffin and kittiwake did not avoid turbines irrespective of the turbine operational status the only species which responded negatively to the wind farm is gannet with reduced abundance in the vicinity of the wind farm however this species large foraging range and wide range of prey means gannet are unlikely to be affected by such avoidance behaviour the report concludes that the beatrice offshore wind farm is very unlikely to have had any detrimental effects on the east caithness cliffs spa breeding colonies

whilst collision risks are easier to understand the assessment of seabird displacement isnt so straightforward and its only right that where there is uncertainty in an impact a precautionary approach is taken however if the precautionary principle is applied excessively there is a risk it will distort robust decision making by presenting assessment outputs which are unrealistic compared to the climate change risk

studies such as those coming out of operational windfarms like beatrice help reduce the uncertainty but if we are to reach net zero targets the results need to be rapidly translated into sncb guidance and new evidence applied to new projects

the beatrice report is available here
 plus

post_text:
france secures european commission approval for 11 billion offshore wind scheme under new eu clean industrial deal framework

the european commission has approved a 11 billion french state aid scheme to support the construction and operation of three floating offshore wind farms marking one of the first major initiatives backed under the clean industrial deal state aid framework cisaf

the 20year scheme structured around twoway contracts for difference cfds will accelerate the deployment of offshore wind in both the atlantic and mediterranean seas while embedding resilience criteria into supply chain selection to reduce dependence on imports particularly from china

project highlights

 three 500 mw floating wind farms
 one off southern brittany two in the mediterranean
 total generation of 66 twh annually enough to power 135 million french households

 transparent competitive bidding
 one winning bidder per zone
 tender includes supply chain resilience as a prequalification and award criterion

 twoway cfd structure
 variable monthly premiums based on market price vs bid reference price
 beneficiaries pay back when electricity prices exceed bid levels

strategic implications

 aligns with the eus 2030 renewable energy targets and the broader clean industrial deal
 helps diversify european clean energy supply chains boosting local content and strategic autonomy
 demonstrates how new eu frameworks like cisaf can drive publicprivate partnerships to accelerate energy transition infrastructure

at blackridge research  consulting we track policylinked clean energy investments offshore wind pipelines and strategic infrastructure developments across europe if youre navigating the offshore wind value chain lets connect to discuss upcoming projects and investment outlook

post_text:
offshore wind power special act proclaimed shift to governmentled development

1 enactment and implementation
 the special act on the promotion of offshore wind power deployment and industry development was enacted on march 25 2024 transitioning offshore wind development to a governmentled planned site allocation system
 the act will take full effect on march 26 2026 with the revision of subordinate regulations enforcement decrees and rules being a key factor

2 key changes and impacts
 governmentled development the government will preselect candidate sites considering economic feasibility environmental impact and public acceptance then select developers through bidding
 restrictions on private approvals individual private wind power development approvals will be prohibited with a grace period allowing approvals until early 2028
 ban on offshore wind measurement devices from the date of enactment permission to install offshore wind measurement devices will be prohibited to prevent indiscriminate site preoccupation
 changes in local governments role existing wind power cluster aggregation district designations may become difficult with potential conversion to designated power zones that grant automatic offshore wind developer status without additional bidding

3 project development process
 the process follows these stages
preliminary zone designation  basic design planning  formation of publicprivate consultative body  designation of power generation zone  developer bidding and selection  approval of implementation plan  construction and completion
 a national offshore wind power development committee under the prime ministers office will be established along with an offshore wind power development task force within the ministry of industry

4 protection of existing projects  future outlook
 existing developers can either continue their projects under current regulations or opt to transition into the new special act framework though criteria are yet to be determined
 new offshore wind project approvals are allowed for three more years until early 2028
 an environmental feasibility assessment will replace traditional environmental and marine utilization impact assessments streamlining regulatory processes
 the bidding system for project selection may undergo changes with further details expected in subordinate regulations

5 industry outlook and challenges
 the special act is expected to boost the offshore wind power industry but the clarity and timing of enforcement regulations remain crucial
 certain provisions eg exemption from preliminary feasibility studies for public enterprises differentiated fees for using public waters require additional guidelines
 there is strong interest in whether the existing wind power bidding system will continue alongside the new special act bidding process

post_text:
sharing a new industry reportmalaysia and singapore explore wind power imports from vietnam

leading energy companies from malaysia singapore and vietnam have signed a joint development agreement to explore the export of clean electricity from vietnam to malaysia and singapore

signed on the sidelines of the asean summit the deal marks a major step toward regional energy integration and supports the asean power grid initiative

the trilateral pact links malaysias malaysian energy consortium myeca joint venture between tenaga nasional berhad tnb and petroliam nasional berhad petronasvietnams petrovietnam technical services corporation ptsc and singapores sembcorp utilities a subsidiary of sembcorp industries

the collaboration aims to tap into vietnams rich offshore wind resources to generate renewable electricity which would be transmitted via subsea cables to peninsular malaysia with future extensions potentially reaching singapore

as part of the agreement the three parties will conduct joint feasibility studies focusing on grid interconnection transmission infrastructure and the integration of energy storage systems to ensure stable power delivery the initiative will be closely coordinated with national regulators and is poised to contribute significantly to regional energy security and the transition to netzero emissions

this tripartite partnership is a milestone in developing crossborder green infrastructure it supports our ambition to build an electricity transit hub for the asean power grid said myec representatives datuk ir megat jalaluddin megat hassan and tan sri tengku muhammad taufik ceo of petronas in a joint statement

vietnam is emerging as a key renewable energy hub in the region with the government prioritising offshore wind development as part of its national energy strategy this agreement reflects ptsc and petrovietnams role in driving vietnams energy transition it marks a new phase of renewable energy investment said tran ho bac general director of ptsc

meanwhile singapore which aims to import 6gw of lowcarbon electricity by 2035 views the agreement as a critical move toward securing sustainable energy sources this initiative reaffirms singapores role as a regional energy hub and supports our emissions reduction commitments added wong kim yin group ceo of sembcorp industries

post_text:
a manifold is a simply an hub for convergence of several oil and gas pipelines for processing and sale it is a large gravitybased structures with a special need for precise location attitude heading and depth determination 


   
 controlled installation ensuring stability and avoiding undesirable forces during the lowering and touchdown of structures
 sensor arrays utilizing comprehensive positioning and orientation sensors attitude sensors and strain gauges
 telemetry systems data transmission from structures to control vessels is critical avoiding electronic interference


the roles of a
in this installation may include but not limited to the following


preinstallation operations
 performing detailed hydroacoustic and geophysical survey of the site for the location of existing structures
 preparation and conditioning of digital display of existing structures like wellheads and pipelines including ghost shape creation
 deploying and calibrating underwater positioning systems preferably lbl arrays
 verification of navigation and underwater positioning systems performance for installation vessel positioning
 conducting preinstallation rov surveys of the site to identify subsurface features and perform final checks
 securing beacons to the manifold


navigational assistance
 providing precise navigation assistance during vessel manoeuvring
 utilizing anchor management systems for positioning anchors accurately if using barge
 displaying surrounding subsurface features to ensure safety
 using an octans gyro equipped rov for fine adjustment of the manifold orientation and heading before touchdown


realtime monitoring
 displaying essential information and digital map to the installation vessel superintendent and personnel including
 structure and vessel position relative to target and existing structures
 digital offset range  bearing between manifold and ghost location depth and attitude information
 ensuring minimal information update times for near realtime accuracy minimum latency


final measurements
 confirming structure position within specified tolerance through comprehensive measurements
 recording final position attitude and depth below mean sea level

precision safety and realtime monitoring are crucial in successful offshore manifold installation proud to have contributed to this project

post_text:
exciting update qatarenergys bul hanine offshore expansion moves forward

a leading asian contractor has emerged as the lowest bidder for two major offshore contracts under qatarenergys bul hanine oilfield redevelopment projecta key step in boosting qatars offshore oil production

 quick history bul hanine field
discovered in 1976 the bul hanine field is one of qatars oldest and most important offshore oilfields located about 80 km east of doha after decades of production qatarenergy formerly qatar petroleum is now investing heavily in redeveloping the field to enhance recovery and extend its lifespan

 why this project matters
part of qatars strategy to sustain oil output alongside its massive lng expansion north field projects
involves new wellhead platforms subsea pipelines and infrastructure upgrades to boost efficiency
strengthens qatarenergys offshore portfolio alongside alshaheen and idd elshargi fields
job opportunities on the horizon
with the contract award expected soon here are some key roles likely to open up
 project managers  engineers offshore civil mechanical electrical
 subsea  pipeline specialists
 hse  quality control professionals
 construction  commissioning experts
 procurement  logistics coordinators
 operations  maintenance technicians

this project will create hundreds of jobs offering opportunities for both local qatari talent and international professionals

post_text:
proud moment from the offshore field 
im pleased to share a previous milestone in my professional journey

from 06 march to 25 april 2024 i had the privilege to serve as a mechanic  operator onboard the britoil diamond vessel for subsea 7 as part of the gallaf batch 3 subsea pipelines and cables project under north oil company noc

during this period i worked on the precommissioning scope epc17 subsea pipelines and cables project ensuring all tasks were performed safely and efficiently

receiving this testimonial means a lot to meit reflects the hard work dedication and teamwork we demonstrated throughout the operation
key highlights
 handson experience in subsea pipeline precommissioning
 high safety standards maintained
 strong collaboration with a multidisciplinary offshore team
 recognized for responsibility performance and knowledge sharing

i want to thank my team supervisors and everyone who supported me during this project im excited to continue growing learning and contributing to future offshore projects

 looking forward to the next opportunity to bring value to the industry

visited one of jera co incs key assets futtsu lng terminal located in chiba prefecture japan commissioned in 1985 it is integrated with 52 gw gas power plant it has undergone expansions to increase its storage and regasification capacities and currently equipped with 12 underground storage tanks onshore and subsea pipelines and functions as critical lng receiving hub supplying gas to surrounding tokyo bay area 

lng receiving hubs are considered a viable solution for meeting the high gas demand in regions such as west java which are located far from declining domestic gas resources

ps futtsu lng terminal receives several cargoes annually from indonesias lng production facilities

   from panels to paddocks  july was an exciting month for ow ocean winds in australia

we kicked things off at the australia wind energy 2026 conference in melbourne where

 pelayo rodrguez alonso head of business development japan  apac joined a panel on how australia can lead in

post_text:
today i close the chapter on an incredible engineering graduate programme at sse renewables 

i am filled with deep gratitude for the journey the learnings and the people who made it all meaningful

a special thank you to alun robinson my programme manager always present and always supporting in every way

my journey began in the development team with ben atkinson and other members of the team laying the foundational knowledge thank you for giving me the space to grow through tasks that sharpened both my technical and problemsolving abilities

then came the delivery team construction  commissioning wherechallenged me with responsibilities i am so proud of which have now directly led to my new role thank you for pushing me and trusting me

in the engineering team i meta mentor who changed the way i approached electrical engineering you didnt just explain concepts you made sure i truly understood them you assigned tasks that pushed me to study deeper apply theory in practice and think like a true engineer and together withwho wasnt just a supervisor but a mentor in every sense shaped my technical depth and career readinessthank you

during my control systems placement im truly grateful tofor your willingness to teach and support me

to my chartership mentorthank you for guiding me through my career manager and cpd recordings with your support im well on my way to becoming a chartered engineer with the iet

toin hr your support has made this experience seamless

a big thank you to everyone i have had the pleasure of working with even if i havent mentioned you by name its been a privilege to learn from and work alongside such talented individuals

throughout this programme i became more studious proactive and efficient i embraced every challenge made use of every skill i had and developed many more i am proud to say that my contributions had real impact across multiple projects and were reflected in the high performance ratings i received from my placements

outside of work i had the privilege of attending conferences company events and most meaningfully spreading the spark as a stem ambassador delivering over 20 hours of outreach to more than 1400 young minds

being in the energy industry has also put me in a position to serve as vice chair in the energy institute young professionals network west midlands allowing me to coorganise knowledge sharing and networking events contributing to the growth of our industry i am also proud to be a member of afbe uk and wes

this experience taught me that its not just about working in a good company but having managers mentors and colleagues who care they are the real difference makers

from monday i begin my next chapter as a commissioning support engineer at

thank you

post_text:
a massive thank you to shadi kalash phd emba prince2 technical manager at simply blue group for delivering an insightful and comprehensive presentation to the students of the leadership in offshore renewable energy systems programme dr kalashs presentation on innovative approaches to wind energy resource assessment site selection and engineering design provided invaluable insights for our future leaders in offshore renewable energy

dr kalash discussed several key aspects of offshore wind development including

 offshore wind site selection  he highlighted the importance of choosing optimal sites for offshore wind farms by balancing environmental social and technical constraints his coverage of irelands south coast designated maritime area plan sc
 offered realworld insights into how projects are mapped and assessed

 wind resource and metocean assessments  students learned how critical it is to measure and analyze wind speeds at hub heights using advanced technologies like
to predict energy yield and design efficient wind farms

 engineering design of offshore foundations  the session compared fixedbottom and floating foundations showcasing the scalability of floating platforms to unlock potential in deeper waters where fixed foundations are impractical

 constraint exploration  dr kalash delved into the complex process of assessing various environmental economic and technical constraints using detailed gis models and heatmaps to identify suitable areas for offshore wind development

key takeaways for the students included the importance of leveraging cuttingedge technologies for wind resource assessment considering both economic and environmental factors in project planning and the growing role of floating wind platforms in the future of offshore wind

leadership in offshore renewable energy systems programme is a collaboration between theand the digital europe project

hammerfest lng plant resumes operations after scheduled maintenance 65 billion cubic meters of gas from hammerfest are flowing to europe again

europes largest lng plant in hammerfest norway has resumed gas exports after scheduled maintenance

after more than three months of scheduled maintenance the liquefied natural gas plant in hammerfest norway has resumed operations reuters reports this was announced on monday by representatives of the terminal operator equinor the plant also known as melkoeya lng was shut down on april 22 the initial plan was to resume operations on july 19 but the timing was adjusted

the hammerfest lng plant europes largest natural gas exporter has a capacity to supply about 65 billion cubic meters of gas annually this volume is equivalent to the daily consumption of approximately 65 million european households and represents around 5 of norways total gas exports

the facility located on the arctic island of melkya processes feedstock from the snhvit field in the barents sea located approximately 143 km offshore the finished product is delivered to consumers in europe via subsea pipelines in the north sea the consortium that owns the facility includes equinor petoro totalenergies vaar energi and harbour energy

post_text:
predictive maintenance in oil and gas revolutionizing fpso operations 

today lets dive into how predictive maintenance is transforming the oil and gas sector with a special focus on fpsos floating production storage and offloading units 

in this highstakes industry where downtime can cost millions per day and safety is nonnegotiable reliability engineering plays a pivotal roleand predictive maintenance is at its core

what is predictive maintenance for fpsos
realtime monitoring sensors on critical components like pumps valves and risers collect data on vibration temperature and pressure feeding into advanced analytics systems

digital twins virtual replicas of fpso systems simulate performance predicting failures weeks in advance for instance a digital twin might detect early signs of corrosion in a subsea pipeline

aidriven insights machine learning algorithms analyze historical and realtime data to forecast maintenance needs reducing unplanned shutdowns by up to 30 according to industry studies
why it matters in oil and gas
an fpso operating in the challenging offshore environment of the presalt layer eg brazils bzios field faces harsh conditionshigh waves corrosion and extreme pressures a single failure in a production pump could halt operations costing upwards of 1 million daily predictive maintenance not only prevents such losses but also enhances safety by minimizing human intervention in hazardous areas

my take
having explored reliability in this sector im fascinated by how technology like iot and ai turns data into actionable insights on an fpso this means fewer risks and more uptimea win for efficiency and sustainability

whats your experience with predictive maintenance in oil and gas

have you seen it in action on an fpso

share your thoughts or connect with me to discuss further

post_text:
it lands on your desk

a tender pack hundreds of pages and a fast approaching deadline 
 
this post is part of the tender panic series i promised to write link to the earlier post in the comments so where do we start when the bid itt instruction to tender folder lands in our inbox 

where do we even begin with the scope of work sow
this is where most planners freeze

with no clear starting point
no milestone list
no execution logic
just 100 200 pages of technical contractual and compliance content

and the instruction to the planner and proposal team is usually
just make the schedule

let me show you how to break this down and extract what really matters even when youre short on time

remember
a you dont need to read the entire document when time is limited
b you dont need the perfect schedule in the first few hours
c you need a clear way to think and a structure to build on
d dont judge the tender by its volume or based on the page count

heres how we can approach it

1 start with a smart search
search for key terms
 project duration
 milestones
 tentative award date
 contractors responsibility
 sequence of activities
 interface  coordination
 engineering deliverables
 construction phasing

these will lead you to scattered but essential inputs for your wbs and scheduling logic and help your team with the project execution plan pep as well

2 break it into disciplines
even if its not grouped well create quick buckets
 engineering
 procurement
 fabrication
 construction onshore offshore
 marine subsea pipelines
 commissioning
 transportation  logistics especially for offshoreislandbased work

this will turn the info dump from the tender into a structure and helps drive your execution logic

3 spot the sequencing cues
look for phrases like
 after completion of
 shall be completed prior to
 interface with
 phased handovers
 staged releases
 required on
 delivery at site

these will help when building timeline logic

4 draft the wbs skeleton
 dont wait for everything to be clear
 start with a highlevel wbs based on disciplines and phases

youll refine it later but this gives you a working base

5 flag whats missing
 if anything critical is unclear say access dates noc requirement shutdowns trainings and qualification requirement or ll items raise it early
 youre not supposed to guess

youre supposed to plan around whats given and highlight whats not

wait for the next post i will try to do it during this week

any other ways by which you all tackle this please comment  it will be helpful for the bidding and planning community

 plus

post_text:
for the past 2 months ive had the amazing opportunity to work as an environmental and sustainability es intern at dominion energy de supporting the electric transmission team in this role i focused on the environmental permitting process more specifically on regulatory approvals from the state corporation commission scc throughout my internship i strengthened my understanding of environmental compliance in the energy sector and expanded my knowledge around the importance of keeping our infrastructure sustainable for humans animals and other environmental concerns alike
 
in addition to my daily duties with es i was able to expand my industry knowledge by touring several de facilities i had the pleasure of touring the coastal virginia offshore wind cvow project  an offshore wind farm located off the coast of virginia beach aiming to provide clean renewable energy to 660000 de customers i also toured the bath county power pump storage station and the surry nuclear power plant which are two of the largest energy power plants in the united states all 3 sites are helping dominion energy achieve its goal of net zero carbon and methane emissions by 2050

and i just cant say enough about the patience guidance and support ofand they were always available to help guide and support me all while affording me numerous opportunities to immerse myself in the dominion energy community i am beyond grateful for this experience and im looking forward to applying my learnings to my future studies at uva and beyond

ukgermany the german transmission system operator gascade gastransport gmbh and britains national gas have signed a mou to explore establishing a hydrogen corridor between the uk and germany in the north sea the project will consist of two offshore pipeline sections the first section from the uk mainland will link with gascades aquaductus pipeline project which connects to the german mainland

the two transmission companies are building upon the latest results of a feasibility study carried out by arup adelphi and dena the planned project aims to establish critical infrastructure that will not only accelerate the decarbonisation of industry through green and lowcarbon hydrogen but also significantly enhance europes energy independence

 managing director at gascade through joint infrastructure projects like this we can leverage the uks significant renewable resources and germanys strategic hydrogen storage and consumption capabilities diversifying energy imports and strengthening european energy security

gascade press release 

feasibility study the potential for exporting hydrogen from the uk to continental europe

post_text:
todays relatively quiet announcement that ge vernova s 18mw haliadex turbine has been cleared for testing in norway is another sign of a quiet revolution in offshore wind

in parallel to ge siemens gamesa has installed its 215 mw prototype in denmark its clear the supply chain has returned to the drawing board not out of retreat but to prepare for whats next the focus is shifting from rapid deployment to smarter more resilient and scalable foundations

beyond turbines the technical landscape is evolving quickly surveys now rely increasingly on unmanned vessels enabling work in harsher conditions and reducing costs installation is becoming more automated and dronebased inspections are set to transform om particularly through the rise of total productive maintenance strategies ai is quietly permeating planning execution and diagnostics setting the stage for more efficient and adaptive operations

meanwhile seabed leasing rounds have slowed and developers seem more cautious more deliberate the feverish pace has given way to something that feels familiar a strategic pause like the one seen in the early 2010s which quietly laid the groundwork for the sectors first boom

that period gave us the transformation of dong into the birth of largescale projects and the emergence of a bankable offshore wind industry today we might be on the cusp of a similar inflection point one that trades speed for substance

crucially this context is encouraging for late entrants in the leasing game like
 entering at a time when technology is maturing supply chains are reorganising and lessons from the first wave have been absorbed may offer real advantages if the right positions are taken now

the next boom wont come from speed it will come from those who use this pause to prepare wisely and i can see a few developers well placed to benefit from that next boom

post_text:
what is digital transformation in wind energy
digital transformation refers to the integration of digital technologies into all aspects of wind turbine operations from design and manufacturing to realtime monitoring and predictive maintenance it enhances efficiency reduces costs and improves sustainability

 key technologies driving the transformation
1 artificial intelligence ai  machine learning
use predictive maintenance fault detection and performance optimization
example ai models analyze sensor data to predict gearbox failures weeks in advance

2 big data  analytics
use wind pattern analysis site selection and energy forecasting
example turbines equipped with thousands of sensors generate terabytes of data daily which is analyzed to optimize blade pitch and yaw

3 digital twins
use virtual replicas of turbines for simulation and realtime monitoring
example operators simulate extreme weather conditions to test turbine resilience without physical risk

4 iot internet of things
use realtime data collection from turbines
example smart sensors monitor temperature vibration and wind speed to adjust turbine behavior dynamically

5 blockchain
use transparent energy certification and peertopeer energy trading
example consumers can buy windgenerated electricity directly from producers using blockchainbased platforms

 realworld example 
rsted a global leader in offshore wind uses digital twins and ai to monitor turbine health and optimize energy output their systems can simulate weather impacts and schedule maintenance before issues arise reducing downtime and increasing roi

 examples of digital transformation in wind turbine operations

 abbs condition monitoring
abbs abilitytm condition monitoring platform uses data visualization and analytics to monitor wind turbine components enabling remote support and predictive maintenance

 siemens digital models
siemens offers digital models of wind turbines simulating various aspects of their performance reducing development time and costs

 technalias digital twin
technalia is developing a digital twin of a wind turbine powertrain to optimize maintenance and reduce operational costs

 vestas digitized manufacturing
vestas is using digital tools to improve manufacturing processes including work instructions and knowledge management

 benefits of digital transformation in the wind turbine industry
 reduced operational costs
 increased energy production
 improved asset management
 enhanced safety
 more sustainable energy production
 faster development and deployment of new wind turbines
 more competitive wind energy

you can add your ideas on digital transformation in your industry and make this post more informative

post_text:
water electrolysis requires direct current dc at low voltage but renewable electricity for green hydrogen production is typically supplied through an ac grid connection converting ac back to dc it is therefore of interest to consider more optimised dcdc connections for largescale green hydrogen plants

therefore the ispt  institute for sustainable process technology in cooperation with hitachi energy and consortium partners equinor hycc rsted port of rotterdam and yara international has completed a feasibility study to explore a hybrid electrical layout incorporating dc and ac connections the study focuses on developing optimised power conversion schemes for a gigawatt gwscale water electrolysis plant

the objective is to prepare a conceptual design for a converter topology that enables the integration of this new electrical layout highlighting both its benefits and limitations

in this study a new electrical layout with innovative power converters has been selected due to its relatively high level of maturity proposed higher efficiency potentially lowest complexity costs and footprint in this article you can read all of the findings and download the report

post_text:
bscplc internet capacity hits 4 tbps doubling in a year under new leadership

bangladesh submarine cables plc bscplc has reached a new milestone with realtime internet traffic capacity hitting 4 terabytes per second tbps as of august 1 2025 the staterun bandwidth provider added its latest terabyte in just three months after crossing 3 tbps in aprila sharp acceleration compared to the eight months it took to add 11 tbps previously
since the start of the current governments term bscplcs total supply has grown by more than 22 tbps marking a yearonyear increase of over 105 this contrasts sharply with the previous administration under which more than 65 of the companys capacity went unused
the surge has been fueled by strategic policy reforms competitive pricing and operational improvements under new leadership regulatory support from the bangladesh telecommunication regulatory commission btrc which requires international internet gateway operators to source at least 50 of their bandwidth from submarine cable providers has further boosted demand
bscplc now supplies over half of the bandwidth consumed by iigs nationwide special pricing for cloud providers data centres and bulk discounts for large users have also strengthened capacity utilisation and revenue
looking ahead the government has approved revised routes for the seamewe 4 5 and 6 submarine cable systems which are expected to add another 17 tbps to the countrys realtime internet capacity upon completion

delmar systems was contracted by saipem to supply the stevmanta vertical load anchors and stevadjuster inline tensioners for the turretmoored fpso firenze at the baleine field offshore cte divoire west africa in 1015m water depth

the anchors and ground chains including the stevadjusters were preinstalled from the anchor handling vessel olympic zeus all the stevmantas were successfully embedded with 165mt bollard pull to break the shear pin and trigger the anchor into its normal loading configuration drag lengths averaged 21m right in the middle of the predicted range and estimated burial depth was 16m below mudline

the fpso was successfully hooked up to the prelaid mooring legs the stevadjusters were used in turn to pretension each leg to the target load this operation typically taking 4 hours on average per leg using only a single vessel

wind of hope now operating in the german north sea 
 
after a successful period supporting offshore wind farms in the uk wind of hope is now joining wind of change in the german north sea this marks an important step in reinforcing our service fleet and ensuring reliable maintenance of our wind farms in the region
 
wind of hope is rsteds second service vessel deployed to support our german offshore operations it complements its sister ship wind of change which has been successfully carrying out maintenance work on the 337 wind turbines since 2019 both ships were specially designed and built to meet the requirements of offshore wind power

with its tailormade design and individual technical capabilities wind of hope is optimally designed for efficient and sustainable maintenance operations

our expansion in recent years has almost doubled the amount of wind power capacity weve installed in the german north sea  our second service vessel will play a key role in keeping energy generation at a high level

the 84metrelong wind of hope offers space for 90 individual cabins which provide a home for our service technicians and crew during their assignments

at we focus on safety and innovative technology the ship has a modern dieselelectric drive with hybrid support which is supplemented by a battery pack this combination ensures sustainable operation and reduces co2 emissions

the gangway is equipped with motion compensation which facilitates safe crossing in the event of waves thanks to the intelligent dynamic positioning control the ship stays in place with a maximum deviation of one metre which increases the safety of our employees during maintenance

we are proud to expand rsteds capacities with wind of hope and to strengthen our contribution to green energy supply in germany

post_text:
today i attended suboptic 2025 in lisbon focusing on masterclasses that covered the full scope of submarine cable systems

in the morning i joined the wet plant design and qualification masterclass presented by qian zhong google  kovsh subcom eduardo mateo nec and jeanfranois baget asn topics included open cable system design technology qualification steps and customer expectations in submarine network rollouts

the afternoon session advances in marine operations and maintenance featured speakers from meta oms group google and clb advisory claire boggis pointed out that the current build and maintenance fleet averages over 25 years in age with only 22 vessels available worldwide highlighting the need for investment in new sustainable ships and talentstressed the need to rethink global maintenance zones and gave insight into predictive maintenance strategies

i think this topic deserves broader attention including from institutions like the european commission especially in relation to cef funding priorities

the final masterclass the dance of the troublemakers legal finance and regulatory was led by representatives from cms baker botts and thebank it provided a project lifecycle view from contractors banks sponsors and tenants a key message permitting should not be an afterthought yet it often is

suboptic highlights how critical and specialized the submarine cable industry is while technical innovation is visible such as the move from singlecore to multicore fiber the operational and business processes still follow traditional telecom approaches theres room and a need for more evolution
tomorrow is the second day and i will see what i will learn more
 plus

post_text:
today i attended suboptic 2025 in lisbon focusing on masterclasses that covered the full scope of submarine cable systems

in the morning i joined the wet plant design and qualification masterclass presented bygoogle  kovsh subcomnec andasn topics included open cable system design technology qualification steps and customer expectations in submarine network rollouts

the afternoon session advances in marine operations and maintenance featured speakers from meta oms group google and clb advisory claire boggis pointed out that the current build and maintenance fleet averages over 25 years in age with only 22 vessels available worldwide highlighting the need for investment in new sustainable ships and talentstressed the need to rethink global maintenance zones and gave insight into predictive maintenance strategies

i think this topic deserves broader attention including from institutions like the european commission especially in relation to cef funding priorities

the final masterclass the dance of the troublemakers legal finance and regulatory was led by representatives from cms baker botts and thebank it provided a project lifecycle view from contractors banks sponsors and tenants a key message permitting should not be an afterthought yet it often is

suboptic highlights how critical and specialized the submarine cable industry is while technical innovation is visible such as the move from singlecore to multicore fiber the operational and business processes still follow traditional telecom approaches theres room and a need for more evolution
tomorrow is the second day and i will see what i will learn more

post_text:
this past fall alongside my work for rsted i had the chance to be part of yale center for business and the environment cbeys inaugural cohort of the clean and equitable and energy development ceed certificate program
 
overall i would recommend ceed at yale for any working professional who is looking to deepen their knowledge of renewable energy project development  be it solar wind geothermal or energy storage  all studied through the lenses of energy environmental and climate justice 

in addition to covering development fundamentals site selection permitting interconnection procurement financing construction and om the fourcourse program also explored more academic topics such as the history of the us environmental justice movement theoretical frameworks for how the world should allocate climate change mitigation costs among nations and progress against un sustainable development goals related to ensuring global access to affordable reliable and clean energy

im not sure a semesterlong certificate program at yale qualifies me to start wearing beat harvard tshirts but i did really enjoy the courses my classmates and visiting the yale campus  not least of which included the school mascot handsome dan xix

post_text:
ever wonder how we check on undersea repeaters without getting wet 

say hello to the lme  line monitoring equipment 

in a submarine cable system stretching thousands of kilometers we cant just knock on a repeaters door when something goes wrong so how do we know whats happening in the deep

lme is the watchdog that sits in the landing station keeping constant tabs on repeater status optical line health and power feed conditions

what lme actually does

 monitors repeater currentvoltage via the pfe

 detects faults along the power path or optical line

 uses supervisory channels to talk to undersea repeaters

 feeds back alerts diagnostics and performance stats

 keeps slte noc and maintenance teams in the loop

vendor line monitoring systems youll see in the field

 alcatel submarine networks asn  alm advanced line monitoring
 nec corporation  nmslc network management system for line control
 subcom  lms line monitoring system

fun fact
a single repeater fault in the middle of the ocean lme will tell you exactly which one is malfunctioning and how severe the issue is no guessing no diving just data

 repost if you like it

follow me for more

post_text:
laying fiber optic cables

laying fiber optic cable requires careful planning and execution to maintain performance and avoid damage here are key precautions to take during fiber optic cable laying

1 preinstallation planning

site survey assess the route for obstacles rocks water buildings etc and underground utilities

cable route design ensure route has minimal bends and follows industry bend radius guidelines

cable selection choose the right type singlemode multimode armored loose tube etc based on application and environment

2 handling precautions

avoid excessive pulling do not exceed the cables maximum tensile strength use pulling grips and dynamometers to monitor tension

minimum bend radius maintain a bend radius of 10x the cable diameter when static 20x when under tension

no crushing or kinking do not step on or place heavy objects over the cable

3 installation practices

proper ducts and conduits use smoothwalled debrisfree conduits avoid sharp edges at entriesexits

cable blowing or pulling use airblown or mechanical pulling methods with lubricant when needed

labeling and documentation label both ends and document the route for future reference and maintenance

4 environmental considerations

moisture protection use waterblocking gelfilled cables or sealed closures in wet or underground areas

uv protection use uvresistant jacketed cables for outdoor aerial installations

rodent protection use armored cables or install protective ducts in rodentprone areas

5 safety measures

use ppe safety glasses gloves and protective clothing when handling fiber

dispose fiber scraps properly use designated containers for fiber shards

follow local regulations obtain permits and mark digging zones especially for underground work

6 testing after installation

visual inspection check for visible damage correct routing and secure terminations

otdr and power meter tests confirm cable integrity loss levels and performance

 subsea cables need better protection due to the geopolitical situation a sequence of intended breaches is a serious risk to our digitalised societies we need political action closer collaboration across sectors  and more redundancy to keep data flowing and stay resilient

repost from submarinenetworkscom the us national science foundation has issued a request for information rfi to facilitate the concept definition of a proposed subsea telecommunications and science instrumentation cable to 
hashtag
 with input from industry academia nonprofits government philanthropic and other interested parties

on august 28 2024 the us national science foundation nsf published in the federal register a document entitled request for information rfi on science research goalsobjectives affecting proposed us antarctic science monitoring and reliable telecommunications smart cable and route design in response to delays to widely publicize the rfi within the science research community to enhance public response and provide sufficient time to adequately consider and respond to the rfi nsf has determined that an extension of the comment period until wednesday january 15 at 1159 pm eastern is appropriate

the antarctic smart cable concept proposes to connect the largest research facility in antarctica the us mcmurdo station with either invercargill new zealand or sydney australia with the global telecommunications infrastructure the cable would incorporate scientific sensors to provide an enduring observational instrumentation platform for the sparsely observed southern ocean specifically the cable proposes to host the point science sensor concept promoted by the united nations intergovernmental oceanographic commission of unesco  the joint task force on science monitoring and reliable telecommunications cables commonly known as
science monitoring and reliable telecommunications the cable would also leverage the rapidly evolving capability of distributed fiber sensing

in response to the 2021 science workshop nsf contracted a comprehensive preliminary conceptfeasibility study known as a desktop study or dts incorporating the unique attributes of implementing a sensorenabled cable to antarctica

the dts addresses two proposed routes for comparison 1
station to sydney australia and 2 mcmurdo station to invercargill new zealand it includes brief assessments of optional extensions from the main cable routes to macquarie island for potential interconnection to the australian research station located there and to nearby international research stations located in the western ross seaterra nova bay area

post_text:
why offshore wind has lagged in india

india with over 70 gw of offshore wind potentialespecially along the coasts of gujarat and tamil nadu then why offshore wind source till lagging in india 

 high costs  financial risks  
offshore projects require significantly more capital investment than onshore due to the complex and expensive nature of installing turbines at sea laying subsea cables and building grid connections
current cost estimates for offshore wind 912 per unit are far higher than for onshore or solar making them commercially unattractive without stronger subsidies or guarantees

 technical  infrastructure challenges
offshore wind demands advanced logisticsindia lacks essential infrastructure such as deepdraft ports supply chains for massive turbines and specialized vessels for transport and maintenance
the grid infrastructure needed to transmit power from sea to shore is still underdeveloped and costly to build

 regulatory  environmental hurdles
projects face long approval timelines due to strict marine regulations and necessary public consultations
resistance from fishing communities in coastal regions reflects concerns about disruption to marine ecosystems and local livelihoods

 policy  market uncertainty
although the national offshore wind energy policy was introduced in 2015 and zones were identified lack of bankable projects and limited experience have deterred investors
government incentives have not been sufficient to offset the massive upfront costs adding to delays

 indias offshore wind vision
 policy commitments  targets
india aims to install 30 gw of offshore wind by 2030 identifying over 70 gw of potential capacity in gujarat and tamil nadu
these plans tie into the broader goal of increasing renewable energy sources in the countrys electricity mix

 pilot projects launched
the first 500 mw offshore wind farms in gujarat and tamil nadu were tendered in 202425 backed by viability gap funding of 7453 crore 900 million
port and grid upgrades are in progress along with tenders for undersea cable and transmission systems these pilot projects are expected to be commissioned by 2029 but currently remain in early planning stages

 future prospects
if the initial projects prove successful they will showcase offshore winds technical and financial viability potentially unlocking largescale development and local supply chains
offshore wind could generate up to 800000 new jobs by 2030
international collaborationwith countries like the uk denmark and the euis helping india gain expertise and develop supporting infrastructure
speeding up progress will require expanded government funding smoother permit procedures upgraded ports and transmission networks and more acceptance from coastal communities

the coming years will decide whether these efforts gather momentumor remain stuck in the planning phase
