post_text:
japan suffers from a lack of physical diversity in cable landings for example the maruyama cls serves 8 cables most of them major internet arteries including ase apg jupiter tpe and adc according to the submarine networks website the country has more than 20 facilities however they are densely concentrated as the map below shows moreover it would not be surprising if many of the are sharing back haul fibre consequently the japanese government is giving money to softbank for the construction of two new cable landing stations in the hokkaido and fukuoka projects because they make nationss telecommunications more robust the projects anchor tenant is the eta east to america subsea cable 

in general i am skeptical of subsidies for a variety of very good reasons namely they usually distort the allocation of resources in pursuit of political gain however aid for new cable landings that are diverse to the existing landing infrastructure may be exception it would be better for the eu to get out of the cable system funding business and focus on low cost ways of promoting physical diversity via edict or subsidies for example the uk government should be deeply concerned that many major cables apollo amiti 2africa grace hopper express glo1 eig yellow and beaufort 2027 land at bude uk divided among 3 landing stations with two vodafone facilities hosting most of them i would advocate subsidizing new cable landing stations that are not only diverse to the usual suspects but also involve new back hual fibre routes to slough equinix manchester and london

the challenge in creating physical diversity in landing infrastructure is simple using an existing cls sharply reduces capex for a new project and accelerates it by avoiding new permits and construction another challenge is latency minimizing latency will lead to cable landings to cluster like they do in bude landing at bude is the shortest path to london the map of japans cable landing stations clearly illustrates a similar clustering tendency carriers tend to ignore the benefits of diversification due to wholesale price pressure another factor is simply corporate myopia as most telecom senior managers have a limited understanding of the business very few have done sales a key factor is that most projects cannot command a premium for physical diversity when i worked for hibernia atlantic our system had a clear diversity edge because it landed several hundred kilometers to the north of bude at southport uk but only a few banks in our customer base were willingness to pay a premium for it in most deals i was forced to match the competitors price and use physical diversity to break the tie

 plus

benchmarking solar onshore wind  offshore wind projects  what really drives the costs

in 2024 the world added over 700 gw of new renewable energy capacity in which solar pv led with 550 gw while wind added 120 gw according to the ieas global energy review 2025 solar and wind now make up 95 of new renewable growth as demand accelerates and project sizes grow accurate cost benchmarking becomes more critical than ever for budgeting contracting and ensuring competitive lcoe

each renewable project includes both hard costs physical construction and equipment and soft costs development design permits financing

solar pv
 hard costs modules inverters mounting systems electrical bos installation labor
 soft costs permits engineering interconnection insurance project overhead

onshore wind
 hard costs turbines blades nacelle hub tower foundation roads substation
 soft costs land lease wind studies permitting project management

offshore wind
 hard costs offshore turbines monopile or jacket foundations subsea cables offshore substations marine vessels
 soft costs marine surveys regulatory approvals grid design studies developer costs

key benchmarking metrics
systemlevel metrics
 installed capex kw or mw
 levelized cost of energy lcoe mwh
 annual om costs

componentlevel metrics
solar pv
 module cost w
 inverter cost w
 racking  bos w

onshore wind
 turbine assembly kw
 foundation cost per turbine
 electrical collection system mw

offshore wind
 turbine mw
 foundationsubstructure mw or unit
 subsea cable km
 offshore substation mw

traditional epcc benchmarking metrics are still useful for renewable energy projects especially for tracking contracts and progress yet to be truly effective i think we might need to break it down further by technology tag componentspecific costs within each phase consider adding soft cost tracking outside the epc scope and including permitting interconnection land use and marine operations

i personally find it challenging to get useful data for components benchmarking unless you start to build your own based on internal projects and gather public information from trusted sources includes ipa cec  renowned project benchmarking data irena reports  global benchmarks for solar wind storage nrel atb us  techspecific capex  lcoe benchmarks iea pvps  iea wind task 26  international cost breakdowns rystad renewablecube  commercial projectlevel capex data and lazard lcoe reports  highlevel cost comparisons across energy types

i am true believer in benchmarking helps improve cost estimate tremendously to stay competitive and credible which benchmarking metric you always check before greenlighting a project

proposed transatlantic cable could link ireland to maryland 
the town of ocean city maryland is currently in talks with tech giant amazon to bring a fiber optic cable ashore all the way across the atlantic from county cork ireland

in june of 2024 amazon filed an application with ireland to begin surveys and site investigations for a proposed subsea cable from castlefreke county cork with a route across the atlantic to landfall on the east coast of the united states according to online records that feasibility study was approved in april of this year

amazons application lists the cables intended purpose as telecommunications connectivity and keeping europe globally competitive

europes digital leadership and global competitiveness is dependent on strong internal and external connectivity the application reads in that regard the commission highlights the importance of improving connectivity with external partners including via subsea cables

post_text:
thursday may 22 2025
 offshore wind energy infrastructure series  summary to date
by michael g harvey  knowledge advocate  retired civil engineer
 as of monday may 19 2025
 introduction harnessing the wind at sea
offshore wind has emerged as a vital pillar in global clean energy strategies with steadier winds and higher generation potential than landbased systems offshore farms are expanding rapidly across europe asia and the americas this growth however brings unique engineering environmental and logistical challengesdemanding innovation across all phases of development
 key insight offshore wind is no longer experimentalits a core solution but requires mastery across disciplines
 part 1 site selection and marine resource assessment
success begins with location wind mapping depth maritime traffic and ecological sensitivity shape site viability early stakeholder engagement is essential
 key insight offshore wind begins not with steelbut with science
 part 2 seabed survey and geotechnical investigation
understanding the seabed is essential for foundation integrity through sonar seismic and core sampling engineers assess soil strength and installation risk
 key insight build from what you cannot see
 part 3 environmental and navigational permitting
this phase ensures a balance between infrastructure and marine ecosystems developers assess habitat impact consult maritime authorities and engage local communities
 key insight the sea does not yield easily it demands foresight respect and more than profit
 part 4 grid connection and export cable routing
a turbine is only useful if its power reaches shore this stage focuses on subsea cable routing landfall integration and regulatory approval
 key insight a turbine without a cable is like a lighthouse without a light
 part 5 foundation design and fabrication
monopile jacket and floating platforms are engineered to match depth seabed and wave dynamics fabrication must meet marinegrade standards and delivery timelines
 key insight build below the waterline with the same care as you build above it
 part 6 turbine procurement and staging logistics
turbines are global assemblies precision scheduling inspection preassembly and marine transport all demand seamless coordination
 key insight success in offshore wind isnt just about building at seaits about getting there efficiently

q how is offshore wind faring in australia

a not that well despite chris bowens blind push for it sometimes economics engineering and practical issues get in the way of the best laid ideological desires

 gippsland dawn  cancelled july 2025
 bass offshore wind energy bowe  withdrawn aprjul 2025 equinor pulled out
 illawarra offshore wind  extraordinary public campaign against project equinor and oceanex choose not to bid bluefloat  gone out of business
 shellharbour  hunter project  axed july 2025 as part of bluefloat exit
  wa offshore zone bunbury  6 developers pull out incl flotation energy copenhagen energy jera  parkwind 2 bidders remain including edf energy
 kingston offshore wind sa shelved december 2024  state planning minister blocked it
 victorian renewable energy terminal port of hastings vic  declared unacceptable under epbc act
 midwest offshore wind farm in wa  axed after withdrawal of copenhagen energy from wa industry

still progressing at this stage include
 the rwe  kent offshore wind farm bass strait
 ortsed offshore australia 1 gippsland
 aurora green  iberdrola ow2 gippsland

post_text:
wind farm vessel type

in wind energy projects several types of vessels are involved in the installation maintenance and operation of offshore wind farms these include

jackup vessels these vessels are equipped with retractable legs that can be extended to the seabed to lift the ship above the water they are commonly used for installing wind turbine foundations and other heavy offshore structures

cablelaying vessels these specialized ships are used for laying the electrical cables that connect the wind turbines to each other and to the shore enabling power transmission from the turbines to the grid

installation vessels these vessels are equipped with cranes and other tools designed for installing the wind turbines including the towers nacelles and blades some of these vessels can handle large components such as the entire wind turbine structure

service operation vessels sovs these are used to transport technicians and equipment to offshore wind farms for ongoing maintenance and servicing of turbines sovs are designed to provide safe comfortable accommodation for workers during offshore operations

survey vessels these vessels are used for preconstruction site surveys to assess the seabed conditions and other environmental factors they are equipped with sonar and other tools for data collection

anchor handling tug supply ahts vessels used to assist in the installation of heavy equipment including the mooring anchors for floating wind turbines they are also involved in transporting supplies to offshore sites

wind farm maintenance vessels these vessels are used for general maintenance tasks such as repairs and parts replacement for turbines they are equipped with cranes and often feature accommodation areas for technicians

floating platforms for floating wind farms for floating wind farms vessels like semisubmersible platforms are used to transport the turbines and anchor them in deeper waters

each of these vessels plays a crucial role in the successful deployment and operation of offshore wind energy infrastructure

credit

octrex holdings

research indicates that saudi arabia possesses substantial wind energy potential especially in regions like aljouf hafar albatin and the red sea coastline studies have assessed wind speeds and power densities across various sites identifying locations suitable for wind energy generation for instance a study focusing on six sites including sharurah and jeddah south provided updated insights into wind energy speeds and their potential impact on energy production

dumat aljandal wind farm

a landmark project in saudi arabias renewable energy landscape is the dumat aljandal wind farm located in the aljouf region this 500 million project is the kingdoms first utilityscale wind farm boasting a capacity of 400 megawatts mw the wind farm comprises 96 wind turbines and is expected to power up to 70000 homes significantly contributing to the nations renewable energy targets

strategic initiatives and future prospects

saudi arabias commitment to renewable energy is evident through various strategic initiatives the renewable energy localisation company relc a division of the public investment fund has formed joint ventures with international companies to advance the kingdoms clean energy infrastructure these partnerships aim to localize up to 75 of the components used in saudi arabias renewable projects by 2030 positioning the country as a major global exporter of renewable technologies

challenges and opportunities

while the prospects for wind energy in saudi arabia are promising challenges such as technological adaptation grid integration and environmental considerations remain however the kingdoms proactive approach in conducting feasibility studies and investing in infrastructure development reflects a strong commitment to overcoming these challenges and harnessing wind energy effectively

saudi arabias venture into wind energy marks a pivotal shift towards sustainable energy solutions with substantial investments and strategic planning the kingdom is poised to become a leading player in the renewable energy sector contributing to global efforts in combating climate change and promoting environmental sustainability

COSMA can contribute to the Dumat Aljandal Wind Farm project by providing Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) services for seabed characterization, bathymetry mapping, cable route mapping, and environmental baseline surveys.

1. Seabed Characterization: COSMA's AUV systems equipped with multibeam echosounders can provide detailed information about the seabed topography, helping in the placement of wind turbine foundations.

2. Bathymetry Mapping: Accurate bathymetric data is crucial for planning and installing underwater cables and foundations. COSMA's AUV systems can generate high-resolution bathymetric maps to support these activities.

3. Cable Route Mapping: The AUVs can be used to map the seabed and identify potential obstacles or hazards that could interfere with cable installation, ensuring a safe and efficient route is chosen.

4. Environmental Baseline Surveys: Before construction begins, it's essential to understand the existing environmental conditions. COSMA's AUV systems can collect data on water quality, sediment composition, and marine life, providing a baseline for future monitoring and assessing potential impacts of the wind farm development.

5. UXO Detection: Given the presence of unexploded ordnance (UXO) in Saudi Arabia's coastal regions, COSMA's magnetometers can help identify and mark any potential threats during the cable route mapping or foundation inspection phases, ensuring safety for workers and minimizing environmental impact.

6. Route Planning and Clearance: By combining bathymetric data with UXO detection capabilities, COSMA's AUV systems can assist in planning safe routes for installation activities, reducing risks and potential delays due to unexpected obstacles or hazards.

post_text:
wind farm vessel type

in wind energy projects several types of vessels are involved in the installation maintenance and operation of offshore wind farms these include

jackup vessels these vessels are equipped with retractable legs that can be extended to the seabed to lift the ship above the water they are commonly used for installing wind turbine foundations and other heavy offshore structures

cablelaying vessels these specialized ships are used for laying the electrical cables that connect the wind turbines to each other and to the shore enabling power transmission from the turbines to the grid

installation vessels these vessels are equipped with cranes and other tools designed for installing the wind turbines including the towers nacelles and blades some of these vessels can handle large components such as the entire wind turbine structure

service operation vessels sovs these are used to transport technicians and equipment to offshore wind farms for ongoing maintenance and servicing of turbines sovs are designed to provide safe comfortable accommodation for workers during offshore operations

survey vessels these vessels are used for preconstruction site surveys to assess the seabed conditions and other environmental factors they are equipped with sonar and other tools for data collection

anchor handling tug supply ahts vessels used to assist in the installation of heavy equipment including the mooring anchors for floating wind turbines they are also involved in transporting supplies to offshore sites

wind farm maintenance vessels these vessels are used for general maintenance tasks such as repairs and parts replacement for turbines they are equipped with cranes and often feature accommodation areas for technicians

floating platforms for floating wind farms for floating wind farms vessels like semisubmersible platforms are used to transport the turbines and anchor them in deeper waters

each of these vessels plays a crucial role in the successful deployment and operation of offshore wind energy infrastructure

post_text:
a new study warns that                  

a report commissioned by the   estimates that the   industry will need to invest   over the next 15 years to upgrade its repair and maintenance fleet

the report predicts that the total length of deployed submarine cables will increase by  during this period while the number of annual repairs is likely to rise by 

according to the study approximately 16 million kilometers of new submarine cable systems will be put into operation between now and 2040 nearly twice the length of decommissioned cables
                  

the reports authors consulting firms telegeography and infraanalytics note that this disconnect increases the risk of submarine cable failures particularly in regions requiring extensive maintenance such as the southwestern and northwestern pacific ocean

                      

as the number of inservice submarine cables grows cable breaks or failures are likely to become more frequent raising concerns about whether there are enough repair vessels to maintain the quality of global internet services

surveys indicate that 70 of maintenance companies and 61 of submarine cable owners believe the existing system will struggle to meet maintenance needs over the next 15 years

  head of infraanalytics stated governments worldwide are increasingly prioritizing the security and resilience of critical submarine infrastructure however geopolitical impacts combined with an aging repair fleet underscore the need to strengthen governmentindustry coordination develop new business models to attract asset investment and foster global cooperation to build an effective and sustainable maintenance ecosystem

  research director at telegeography commented this study highlights the urgent need to realign investments in todays digital economy infrastructure to match maintenance capabilities our goal in publishing this report is to equip all stakeholders with the knowledge needed to support a safer more resilient and futureready submarine cable ecosystem

post_text:
why offshore wind has lagged in india

india with over 70 gw of offshore wind potentialespecially along the coasts of gujarat and tamil nadu then why offshore wind source till lagging in india 

 high costs  financial risks  
offshore projects require significantly more capital investment than onshore due to the complex and expensive nature of installing turbines at sea laying subsea cables and building grid connections
current cost estimates for offshore wind 912 per unit are far higher than for onshore or solar making them commercially unattractive without stronger subsidies or guarantees

 technical  infrastructure challenges
offshore wind demands advanced logisticsindia lacks essential infrastructure such as deepdraft ports supply chains for massive turbines and specialized vessels for transport and maintenance
the grid infrastructure needed to transmit power from sea to shore is still underdeveloped and costly to build

 regulatory  environmental hurdles
projects face long approval timelines due to strict marine regulations and necessary public consultations
resistance from fishing communities in coastal regions reflects concerns about disruption to marine ecosystems and local livelihoods

 policy  market uncertainty
although the national offshore wind energy policy was introduced in 2015 and zones were identified lack of bankable projects and limited experience have deterred investors
government incentives have not been sufficient to offset the massive upfront costs adding to delays

 indias offshore wind vision
 policy commitments  targets
india aims to install 30 gw of offshore wind by 2030 identifying over 70 gw of potential capacity in gujarat and tamil nadu
these plans tie into the broader goal of increasing renewable energy sources in the countrys electricity mix

 pilot projects launched
the first 500 mw offshore wind farms in gujarat and tamil nadu were tendered in 202425 backed by viability gap funding of 7453 crore 900 million
port and grid upgrades are in progress along with tenders for undersea cable and transmission systems these pilot projects are expected to be commissioned by 2029 but currently remain in early planning stages

 future prospects
if the initial projects prove successful they will showcase offshore winds technical and financial viability potentially unlocking largescale development and local supply chains
offshore wind could generate up to 800000 new jobs by 2030
international collaborationwith countries like the uk denmark and the euis helping india gain expertise and develop supporting infrastructure
speeding up progress will require expanded government funding smoother permit procedures upgraded ports and transmission networks and more acceptance from coastal communities

the coming years will decide whether these efforts gather momentumor remain stuck in the planning phase

post_text:
short and sweet  but full of important conversations sharp debates and strong messages

this year i only had one day at folkemdet  but it was a good one i joined my colleague sofia lisa dinesen who took part in several timely debates on digital infrastructure data centers and the geopolitical forces shaping our digital future

one key concern raised during the day danish companies are increasingly uneasy about relying on noneuropean cloud providers if we want to catch this momentum and help companies stay in control we need to act faster  politically and practically  to expand local capacity

geopolitics was a recurring theme the uncertainty about what the global superpowers might do next is real  and it highlights the need for stronger infrastructure better protection of our subsea cables and faster permitting processes if denmark wants to stay competitive

thanks to the organisers and tofor creating space for such relevant and good discussions

already looking forward to next year and once again to reconnect with familiar faces and meet new ones along the way

delighted to chair and convene the australia india cables dialogue 2025 strengthening submarine cable connectivity resilience and supply chains this week in perth  australias indian ocean capital 

this extraordinary event brought together australian and indian delegations comprising government officials industry leaders and academic subject matter experts to deliberate how best to protect submarine cable networks 

our expert delegations addressed myriad critical issues pertaining to submarine cable networks including

 advancing australiaindia cooperation on the security resilience and expansion of submarine cable networks across the indopacific

 addressing emerging strategic risks to undersea cable infrastructure posed by rising geopolitical tensions seabed warfare and foreign influence in global cable markets

 identifying and assessing connectivity gaps across the indopacific with a focus on expanding trusted and secure digital infrastructure

 generating concrete policyoriented recommendations for government and industry stakeholders in both nations and inform broader indopacific digital infrastructure strategies

immense thanks to my project collaborators profand profof thefor joint stewardship of this project

many thanks toandatplusfor hosting our delegation for an extraordinarily interesting cable landing station site visit

special thanks to thefor supporting this initiative as part of its australiaindia cyber and critical technologies partnership program andat thefor supporting

as an electrical quality control qc engineer your primary responsibility is to ensure that all electrical installations and materials used on a project meet the required quality standards project specifications nationalinternational codes and client requirements you play a critical role in preventing defects ensuring compliance and verifying that the work is done right the first time

below is a detailed breakdown of your key responsibilities and tasks as an electrical qc

study electrical design drawings specifications
understand client and consultant requirements

preinspection

review material submittals datasheets and certificates of compliance

visually inspect delivered electrical materials
confirm manufacturer model rating and condition
raise material inspection requests mirs for consultantclient approval

conduct preinstallation checks verify that materials and conditions are suitable

monitor

termination

site observations

post_text:
eu in talks to fund fleet to repair damaged subsea cables

by gian volpicelli and andrea palasciano

feb 15 2025 bloomberg the european union is mulling a publicprivate initiative worth hundreds of millions of euros to buy ships that can promptly repair subsea cables in case of damage or sabotage the blocs tech chief said 

we are discussing now with member states what would be the amount that is needed henna virkkunen the european commissions executive vice president for technological sovereignty security and democracy said on the sidelines of the munich security conference when it comes to security we see that theres an urgent need for action

read more baltic undersea cable between latvia and sweden damaged by external force

in recent months there have been a string of incidents in the baltic sea in which telecommunication and power cables strung across the sea floor between countries were damaged by passing ships while it is unclear whether these disruptions were accidental or intentional they have spurred the eu to focus on its infrastructures resilience including by ramping up the continents cablerepairing fleet

subsea cables carry internet and power connections across countries and continents and their loss can cause disruptions to digital services including web access and payments and force telecommunications providers to reroute traffic more than 95 of global data traffic goes through subsea cables according to the international cable protection committee

the cables themselves are about as thick as a garden hose and can be exposed to damage  from natural events like earthquakes accidents like fishing trawlers dragging equipment across the sea bed and from deliberate sabotage the industry relies on a small aging fleet of repair ships with fewer than 100 to cover the globe french phone company orange sa launched a new vessel in 2023 for 50 million 525 million

the shipprocurement drive would be very much a publicprivate partnership with the eu individual countries and telecommunications companies all likely to chip in everybody has to participate virkkunen said

the necessary funds from the eu side will be reallocated from the existing budget given that the next budget wont be implemented until 2028 she said the european commission the eus executive body is planning to release more details in its action plan in the next few weeks

a delegation from the commission is set to travel next week to virkkunens home country of finland one of the member states most affected by cable damages as the eu prepares to release three papers dealing with defense internal security and preparedness strategies

offshore wind substations a key player in the energy transition 

now that i work in this sector i would like to share some information about it offshore wind substations are transforming the way we generate and distribute clean energy these structures not only receive and transform the energy generated by wind turbines but they also enable efficient transport to the onshore grid providing a more reliable and sustainable energy supply so what are the benefits of investing in offshore substations lets break it down

 higher generation capacity
thanks to their location in open water offshore wind farms benefit from stronger and more consistent winds increasing power generation offshore substations step up this energy to high voltage allowing it to be transmitted long distances with minimal losses

 reduction of co emissions
by channeling wind energy into distribution networks offshore substations help reduce reliance on fossil fuels decreasing greenhouse gas emissions each kwh of wind energy generates up to 90 fewer emissions than conventional energy sources

 less visual and noise impact onshore
positioned offshore substations and wind farms avoid the visual and noise impacts that can be a concern for onshore installations this makes them ideal for areas near urban communities providing clean energy without disrupting local surroundings

 job creation and economic development
the installation and maintenance of these infrastructures create jobs and promote technological innovation in key sectors such as engineering underwater robotics and environmental monitoring systems

 marine habitat protection 
research suggests these structures act as artificial reefs offering shelter and food for marine species with sustainable construction and monitoring practices we can advance toward an energy model that respects ecological balance
as the world moves toward decarbonization goals offshore wind energy and marine substations stand as vital allies these infrastructures not only represent a commitment to sustainability but also an opportunity to produce energy safely cleanly and efficiently

post_text:
decommissioning in the oil and gas industry is the process of safely retiring offshore platforms wells pipelines and associated infrastructure after their productive life ends this complex procedure requires strategic planning engineering expertise and adherence to regulatory and environmental standards it typically progresses through the following key stages

1 early planning and assessment

decommissioning begins with a feasibility study and development of a decommissioning plan this includes evaluating options such as full removal partial removal or leaving structures in situ depending on environmental safety and economic considerations a detailed inventory of assets is prepared and environmental impact assessments are conducted stakeholder engagement including regulators environmental agencies and local communities is crucial to address concerns and secure necessary approvals

2 engineering and preparation

this stage involves detailed engineering design and planning site surveys are conducted to map subsea infrastructure and seabed conditions risk assessments are carried out to mitigate safety and environmental hazards operators develop execution plans covering all activities including the cleaning of pipelines and equipment to remove hydrocarbons and hazardous materials scheduling and cost estimation ensure resources are allocated effectively while permits and approvals are finalized

3 offshore execution

the execution phase is the most resourceintensive and involves
 plugging and abandonment pa wells are permanently sealed with cement plugs to prevent any future hydrocarbon leakage
 subsea infrastructure removal pipelines cables and manifolds are either removed or left in place based on approved plans
 platform removal the topside facilities and jacket are dismantled and lifted onto vessels for transport to shore advanced technologies such as remotely operated vehicles rovs are used to enhance safety and efficiency

4 onshore disposal and recycling

removed materials are transported to onshore facilities where they are sorted for disposal recycling or reuse metals like steel are typically recycled while hazardous materials are treated and disposed of according to environmental regulations

5 site remediation and monitoring

the final stage involves cleaning and restoring the seabed to a natural or agreed baseline condition longterm monitoring ensures that no environmental or structural risks remain

conclusion

decommissioning is a critical part of the asset lifecycle by combining strategic planning technological innovation and collaboration operators can ensure the process is safe costeffective and environmentally sustainable

post_text:
pagepark is supporting sses plan to convert the categorya listed sloy power station on the banks of loch lomond into a new pumped storage hydro scheme the project last week reached a milestone which saw the submission of a section 36 planning application to scottish government ministers subject to a positive consenting outcome sse renewables hopes to make a final investment decision on sloy in late 2027 and to fully adapt and commission the new pumped storage scheme by the end of 2030

sloy power station is britains largest conventional hydro power plant and has been in operation since 1950 sse renewables is proposing to convert the existing hydroelectric scheme into a pumped storage scheme by introducing new pumps located in the grounds of the existing building these new pumps would enable water to be lifted from loch lomond to loch sloy using the existing pipelines and tunnels during times of low demand typically overnight or times of oversupply when there is too much renewable energy being generated this would enable energy to be stored at loch sloy until it is required during periods of higher demand

pagepark has worked with sse and ash design  assessment to develop design proposals for the setting of these new pumps which are located primarily below ground a new main pump hall housing an overhead gantry crane celebrates the engineering feats proposed for the site while remaining subservient to the existing tarbolton  ochterlonydesigned building and as far as possible preserving views through a largely transparent new structure the proposed extension picks up subtle clues from the existing building in massing neoclassical composition and materiality

find out more about the project at

post_text:
sse renewables has submitted planning application to convert the existing sloy power station on loch lomonds banks into a pumped storage hydro scheme 

the proposed project aims to introduce a pumping capacity of up to 100mw enabling the facility to deliver up to 16gwh of longduration electricity storage this enhancement would allow the station to provide continuous flexible renewable energy for up to 100 hours thereby bolstering energy security and supporting the balance of a renewablesled energy system during periods of low wind or sunlight

as part of the redevelopment sse renewables also plans to upgrade the existing 325mw g4 turbine to match its sister units increasing the stations total generating output by 75mw to 160mw

the project is expected to support up to 70 jobs during its design development and construction phases

subject to approval sse renewables aims to make a final investment decision on the sloy project by late 2027 with the goal of fully adapting and commissioning the new pumped storage scheme by the end of 2030

great stakeholder meeting in kolding  advancing marine multiuse and sustainable innovation 
 
 on november 2021 a twoday stakeholder meeting took place in kolding focused on marine multiuse win and the eu lighthouse projects ultfarms and olamur were the center of attention at the meeting these ambitious initiatives explore the integration of lowtrophic aquaculture with fossilfree energy systems thus can we grow seaweed and mussels within offshore windfarms

what is the market potential for seaweed and mussel products

discussions also covered topics such as the importance of site selection barriers to obtaining permits and consumer acceptance of the cultivated seaweed and mussels at the pilot sites

exciting development in australias offshore wind industry bunbury designated as offshore wind zone 

the australian government has officially marked out a 3995 km region off the coast of bunbury wa for offshore wind development this decision sets the stage for significant investments in renewable energy and the creation of new job opportunities

 location the zone begins approximately 20 km off the coast of western australia stretching up to 90 km from bunbury
  potential capacity the area has the potential to generate up to 114 gw of clean energy
 jobs it is estimated that over 7000 construction jobs and more than 3500 ongoing jobs will be created
 public consultation the initiative received over 2600 submissions leading to adjustments in the zone to safeguard marine life fishing activities and cultural heritage

 whats on the horizon
feasibility license applications are set to open on june 25 2025 and close on august 24 2025
developers will conduct environmental assessments and engage with local communities
construction may commence in the early 2030s pending necessary approvals and feasibility studies
this development aligns with western australias goal to phase out coal and achieve an 80 reduction in emissions by 2030 marking a significant stride towards australias renewable energy objectives

post_text:
alarm as german offshore wind tenders fail

germanys offshore wind sector is facing a major setback after two major north sea tenders totalling 25 gw and intended for commissioning in 2030 and 2031 failed to attract any bids for the first time the auctions held in august 2024 and overseen by the federal network agency reflected growing unease among developers amid challenging site conditions and shifting market dynamics

economy minister katharina reiche voiced concern at a berlin news conference questioning whether the chosen sites  located in deep waters with high risk of foundation erosion and other structural obstacles  were suitable for development she argued that potential risks for developers may have been underestimated and called for a critical review of how offshore projects are being designated

reiche also pointed to a wider reluctance among customers to commit to longterm power purchase agreements especially given volatile electricity prices that have seen negative periods making revenue streams less predictable current auction designs she said might need reform along lines already adopted in the uk to better protect investor confidence and germanys renewable ambitions

industry associations includingand the german offshore wind energy association directly linked the auctions failure to rising project costs geopolitical supply chain disruptions and an unpredictable market risking investment stability the countrys installed offshore wind capacity has remained flat at 92 gw since the end of 2024 with 19 gw of new turbines still under construction

pressure is now mounting for the german government to rethink auction rules and possibly introduce ukstyle contracts for difference and improved power purchase agreements to attract future investment

both failed tenders will be resubmitted for auction in june 2026 as the government races to meet its offshore wind targets and preserve germanys status as a renewable energy leader

 followfor all the latest news daily from the global power generation industry

uno de los objetivos de la red colombiana de investigadores de energa elica marina es servir como puente entre la investigacin y la sociedad civil promoviendo el debate informado sobre el desarrollo de la energa elica marina en colombia

por eso nos enorgullece compartir nuestra primera aparicin en medios nacionales resultado del trabajo colectivo del grupo ambiental tras la sesin del 30 de enero donde analizamos el proyecto de trminos de referencia para estudios de impacto ambiental en proyectos de energa elica marina este anlisis lleg auno de los principales peridicos de colombia

nuestra directorafue entrevistada para compartir nuestra visin

 nuestra perspectiva sobre los trminos de referencia

 deben diferenciarse claramente de los estudios aplicados a proyectos de energa elica terrestre y offshore oil  gas
 deben basarse en un enfoque de riesgo priorizando los impactos ambientales especficos de la energa elica marina
 proponemos que el gobierno elabore estudios de impacto ambiental estratgicos como lo han hecho otros pases para informar la planificacin espacial marina y la seleccin de reas para estos proyectos

 investigador del sei y miembro de nuestra red tambin fue entrevistado y realiz aportes sobre el componente social de los trminos

 para conocer ms sobre nuestro anlisis y las contribuciones del grupo ambiental les invitamos a leer el artculo siguiendo el enlace del primer comentario

 qu opinan sobre el papel de los estudios ambientales en la regulacin de esta industria los leemos

 bridging research and civil society our first national media appearance

one of the key objectives of the colombian offshore wind research network is to serve as a bridge between research and civil society fostering informed discussions on offshore wind energy development in colombia

thats why we are proud to share our first national media appearance a result of the collective work of our environmental task force after our january 30 session where we analyzed the terms of reference for environmental impact studies for offshore wind projects our insights reached el espectador one of colombias leading newspapers

our director margarita nieves was i nterviewed to share our perspective

 our take on the terms of reference
 they must be clearly distinguished from environmental studies applied to onshore wind and offshore oil  gas projects
 they should adopt a riskbased approach focusing on the specific environmental impacts of offshore wind
 we propose that colombia adopts strategic environmental impact assessments as other countries have done to guide marine spatial planning and site selection for these projects

 read the full article here  el espectador

post_text:
what is oceanographic survey 



an oceanographic survey is the study and mapping of ocean characteristics including water depth seabed topography tides currents water temperature and marine ecosystems

 it is essential for marine navigation resource exploration environmental monitoring and coastal development



types of oceanographic surveys



1 hydrographic surveying  measures water depth seabed contours and underwater hazards for safe navigation



2 geophysical surveying  examines the seabed structure sediment layers and geological formations


3 geotechnical surveying  collects seabed soil samples to determine the stability for marine structures eg bridges ports oil rigs


4 physical oceanography  studies water temperature salinity and currents



5 biological oceanography  examines marine life ecosystems and biodiversity



key tools  equipment used


 multibeam echo sounders mbes  maps seabed topography



 side scan sonar  provides images of underwater objects and terrain


 ctd sensors  measures conductivity temperature and depth of seawater



 subbottom profilers  detects sediment layers beneath the seabed



 remotely operated vehicles rovs  autonomous


underwater vehicles auvs  underwater robots used for deepsea exploration



applications of oceanographic surveys




 marine navigation  port development  ensures safe shipping routes and efficient port construction


 coastal  offshore engineering  supports bridge pipeline and offshore wind farm construction


 environmental monitoring  studies climate change effects pollution and marine biodiversity


 oil  gas exploration  identifies underwater oil and gas reserves


 fisheries  aquaculture  helps manage fish stocks and sustainable marine farming

the wind turbine nacelle market is evolving rapidly as manufacturers focus on enhancing the structural integrity and performance of nacelles to support the increasing size and capacity of modern wind turbines nacelles housing critical components such as the gearbox generator and drivetrain are being optimized with advanced materials and thermal management systems to withstand harsh environmental conditions while improving efficiency the growing deployment of offshore wind farms is further accelerating innovation in nacelle design emphasizing corrosion resistance modular construction and remote monitoring capabilities

post_text:
delighted to talk about the art of the possible with minister jack chambers td minister for public expenditure infrastructure public service reform and digitalisation at government buildings last week  in my capacity as an eu climate pact ambassador

we had one of the most energising and wideranging conversations ive had on climate infrastructure and public leadership no topic was off the table  from offshore wind to evs reforestation to satellites the future of agriculture to data centres grassroots activism to national policy

we spoke about irelands ambition  but also the realworld blockers still holding us back planning infrastructure delivery community buyin and empowerment

i shared a bit about my background  growing up on a farm seeing our fields flood and forests fall in storms  and how those moments pushed me towards climate action and advocacy

that path took me froms climate ambassador programme to thes eu climate pact and into my time at where ive had the chance to work with brilliant teams and clients solving complex problems

what stood out most was a shared sense that ireland has everything it needs to lead  people energy ideas  but we have to unlock delivery that means investing in infrastructure empowering communities and backing young people with real tools not just words

jack was incredibly generous with his time and thoughtful in his outlook i left with plenty to reflect on  and even more motivation

theres still a way to go but conversations like this remind me that there are good people thinking deeply about the future

and that gives me hope
liam

post_text:
application of monel alloy in seawater environments

corrosion resistance of monel alloy in seawater applications
the high corrosion resistance of monel alloy in seawater is one of its most distinct advantages in marine applications this alloy contains approximately 67 nickel 30 copper along with small amounts of iron manganese and other metals these elements form an oxide film on the metal surface preventing seawater penetration monel alloy also resists pitting corrosion and crevice corrosion caused by the high chloride content in seawater consequently monel is favored over other materials susceptible to seawater corrosion such as stainless steel and carbon steel

strength and durability of monel alloy

monel alloy is also renowned for its high strength and durability making it an ideal choice for seawater applications the alloy exhibits excellent mechanical properties at both low and high temperatures enabling it to withstand extreme weather conditions vibrations and impacts monel alloy is additionally resistant to intergranular corrosion which refers to corrosion along grain boundaries that damages the metal when properly fabricated and maintained monel components can last for many years reducing the need for costly repairs or replacements

applications of monel alloy in the marine industry

the unique properties of monel alloy make it an ideal material for various marine applications it is commonly used in constructing seawater piping systems due to its ability to prevent fouling and scaling buildup monel alloy fasteners are also employed in shipbuilding and marine engineering for their high tensile strength and resistance to degradation under harsh seawater conditions heat exchangers valves pumps and other marine components are often manufactured from monel alloy because of its resistance to erosion stress corrosion and chemical attack

examples of monel alloy use in seawater applications

shipbuilders have long relied on monel alloy for producing components that must operate in seawater environments one common application is in the construction of propellers shafts and other propulsion system parts where the materials strength durability and seawater resistance can make a significant impact another example is in the oil and gas industry where monel is used in offshore drilling and exploration subsea components and pipeline maintenance the chemical processing and power generation industries also extensively use monel alloy as it outperforms most other materials in corrosive environments

conclusion
the high corrosion resistance strength and durability of monel alloy make it an excellent material for seawater applications in the marine industry

one_sentence_description: Enerzix is a company that provides Owner's Engineering services for energy projects, specializing in renewable energy, power grid, and battery energy storage systems.
project_summary: Enerzix is providing owners engineering services for various energy projects, including renewable energy (solar and wind), battery energy storage systems, power transmission, distribution, substations, grid expansion, interconnections, and hybrid offgrid power systems.
cosma_opportunity:
COSMA could potentially contribute to Enerzix's energy projects by providing Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) services for the following survey needs:

1. UXO detection: Utilize magnetometers mounted on AUVs for underwater unexploded ordnance (UXO) detection during bathymetric mapping and seabed characterization surveys.

2. Bathymetry mapping: Employ sonar and multibeam echosounders on AUVs to create high-resolution 3D maps of the seafloor, which can be used for route planning and clearance, foundation inspection, and cable route mapping.

3. Route planning and clearance: Leverage photogrammetry systems on AUVs to generate detailed visual surveys of the seabed, aiding in the identification of potential hazards or obstacles during the planning phase of energy projects.

4. Foundation inspection: Utilize AUV-mounted cameras for close-up inspections of underwater foundations, helping to ensure their integrity and stability before, during, and after construction.

5. Cable route mapping: Employ sonar and multibeam echosounders on AUVs to map the seabed and identify potential obstacles or hazards that may interfere with cable routes for power transmission and distribution systems.

6. Seabed characterization: Use AUV-mounted sensors to gather data on the physical properties of the seabed, such as sediment composition, hardness, and density, which can inform foundation design and construction decisions.

7. Environmental baseline surveys: Deploy AUVs equipped with water quality sensors to collect data on temperature, salinity, dissolved oxygen levels, and other environmental parameters, helping to establish a baseline for future monitoring efforts and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements.

By collaborating with Enerzix, COSMA can help deliver high-quality, reliable, and compliant AUV services that support the successful execution of various energy projects, contributing to the acceleration of the transition to a sustainable energy future.

post_text:
naturebased solutions for coastal erosion study tour to the netherlands

as part of ongoing efforts to enhance coastal resilience in lagos i had the privilege of leading a delegation from the lagos state ministry of waterfront infrastructure development on a technical study tour to the netherlands focused on naturebased solutions nbs for coastal erosion and flood mitigation

given lagos unique topography  with much of the city lying below sea level  the threat of sealevel rise tidal surges and shoreline retreat poses significant environmental and socioeconomic risks naturebased solutions such as dune restoration wetland regeneration and hybrid infrastructure present viable sustainable alternatives to traditional grey infrastructure

the a global pioneer in integrated water resources management  continues to offer valuable insights having reclaimed 17 of its land from the sea through innovative ecologically sound interventions

a major milestone during the tour was the formal signing of a contract betweenand a dutch consortium  and van oord for an initial investment to undertake a comprehensive feasibility study on integrated coastal zone management for the lagos coastline

liberia second subsea cable for five west african countries

july 21 2025
 

liberias ministry of posts and telecommunications has launched a collaborative initiative with the ecowas commission for infrastructure energy and digitalization and the world bank to deploy a second subsea cable connecting liberia and four other west african countries

according to a ministry press release issued last week the second submarine cable project is designed to provide essential connectivity for liberia gambia guineabissau guinea and sierra leone

the project is also intended to establish redundancy for the regions connectivity as each of the five countries currently have only one international subsea connection via the africa coast to europe ace cable

post_text:
five years ago the uk was heading into fullon covid lockdown just before the 23rd march 2020 deadline i was frantically driving around the northeast of england visiting ports to help us make a final decision on the location of the dogger bank operations centre

the winning location was the mighty port of tyne at that time the site was somewhat derelict but with so much potential due to covid and a couple of job moves i never got to see the operations  maintenance om centre  until now so a personally special visit for me in newcastle and middlesbrough so heres some highlights from my northeast road trip 

 dogger bank is the worlds largest offshore wind farm in construction with three phases at 12gw each
 the ownership is split across4040 20
 the control room will monitor 5 of the uks electricity
 400 longterm jobs are supported in the operations phase and 2000 across construction
 the base was designed by a newcastlebased ryder architecture and meets the uk green buildings net zero framework

in the pics you will also see part of the dogger bank c converter station whereshowed us round the site whereis commissioning the site to be energised in april 26 the impact that offshore wind makes in terms of jobs and investment on land and of course sea is phenomenal behind the converter station is the old ici petrochemical plant and you can see the remnants of the closed steel mill at redcar if you want evidence that offshore wind is renewing industrial areas of the past look no further

ps thanks torune rnvik for helping us all make such a fine choice for an om base

post_text:
performed insulation resistance ir testing before cable laying  a critical step for electrical reliability and safety

as part of our quality assurance process onsite i recently conducted an insulation resistance ir test using a megger before proceeding with the cable laying activity this is a vital preinstallation check that helps ensure the integrity reliability and safety of electrical cables especially in harsh or industrial environments

 why it matters
before installation cables are susceptible to insulation damage during transportation handling or storage testing insulation resistance at this stage allows us to

1 detect insulation degradation cuts or moisture ingress
2 prevent future faults or short circuits
3 ensure compliance with iecieee standards
4 save costs associated with troubleshooting and rework after installation

 test procedure highlights

1 conducted using a calibrated digital megohmmeter megger
2 applied test voltages typically 500v 1000v or 5000v depending on cable rating
3 measured resistance in megaohms mbetween conductor and earth and between conductors
4 ensured all values were well above acceptable minimum thresholds eg 100 m

 this proactive approach not only demonstrates our commitment to industry best practices but also enhances the overall safety and performance of the electrical system being deployed

cable testing is more than a formality  its a strategic safeguard against premature failure and operational downtime

post_text:
on july 9 2025 i defended my undergraduate thesis feasibility study for the development of a wind farm by an energy community in the prefecture of serres as part of my integrated masters in electrical and computer engineering at aristotle university of thessaloniki auth

using real consumption data and a site selected through an existing multicriteria analysis i modelled several configurations in homer grid to assess their technical and economic performance for a 50member energy community

the findings highlight how communityowned renewable projects when wellsited and appropriately scaled can meet energy needs efficiently while strengthening local ownership and participation in a more democratic energy transition

im deeply grateful to my supervisor asst prof for his support and muchneeded positive outlook throughout the process
looking forward to graduation and what comes next

you can read the full thesis here

post_text:
us aims to ban chinese technology in undersea telecommunications cables  4 clips  1 the federal communications commission said on wednesday it plans to adopt rules to bar companies from connecting undersea submarine communication cables to the united states that include chinese technology or equipment
  we have seen submarine cable infrastructure threatened in recent years by foreign adversaries like china fcc chair brendan carr said in a statement we are therefore taking action here to guard our submarine cables against foreign adversary ownership and access as well as cyber and physical threats
  the united states has for years expressed concerns about chinas role in handling network traffic and the potential for espionage the us has broad data security concerns about the network of more than 400 subsea cables that handle 99 of international internet traffic
 since 2020 us regulators have been instrumental in the cancellation of four cables whose backers had wanted to link the united states with hong kong
 carr said the fcc is taking action to guard our submarine cables against foreign adversary ownership and access as well as cyber and physical threats


2  three stateowned chinese telecommunications companies are major players in the ownership and investment of these cables china mobile china telecom and china unicom these companies have ownership stakes in many cables
 for example
 1 china mobile has invested in at least 8 cables
 2 china telecom has invested in 12 cables
 3 china unicom has invested in 11 cables
 it is important to note that these companies also participate in consortia with other global companies so ownership isnt always exclusive to china  the national bureau of asian research

3 exclusive china plans 500 million subsea internet cable to rival usbacked project  chinese stateowned telecom firms are developing a 500 million undersea fiberoptic internet cable network that would link asia the middle east and europe to rival a similar usbacked project the plan is a sign that an intensifying tech war between beijing and washington risks tearing the fabric of the internet


4 map  2018  version 2 mapping chinas global telecom empire
this version of the gateway house map on chinas expanding global telecom empire identifies some more telecommunication assets  opticfibre and satellite ground stations  that beijing is working on in south and central america africa myanmar the indian ocean region and mainland china besides the existing ones such as the pakistan east africa cable express peace

post_text:
pacific light cable network profile
the plcn project was originally intended to provide the lowest latency path linking hong kong to the united states at this time in 2018 the chinese government was still tolerating democratic dissent in hong kong and had not yet passed its draconian national security laws so while chinaus relationships were tense they had not completely disintegrated google and facebook teamed up with a mysterious chinese owned startup company pacific light data communication to finance and own the cable google owns one fibre pair on the system and also provides the taiwanese and american landings facebook owns one fibre pair and pldc owns the other four tyco known today as subcom built the system

eventually google and facebook realized the federal communications commission fcc would never approve a cable connecting hong kong to the us or one that had chinese ownership so google and facebook refiled the landing application based on the common understanding that the chinese would sell their ownership in pldc to a acceptable third party and that the hk landing would never be lit the fcc accepted this new proposal and all conditions were met so the cable went live in january 2022 a canadian family office purchased pldc at a bargain basement price of 145 million so the system today passes traffic between taiwan and the philippines and the united states

in terms of technology the cable is noteworthy for being one of the first to use the previously untapped lband frequencies along with the standard cband spectrum to achieve very high per fibre pair throughput for a spatial division multiplexing system most sdm systems that traverse the ultralong distances of the pacific typically are designed for initial 12 tbps to 15 tbps per fibre pair tyco subcom used the l band to get achieve initial design throughput of 24 tbps and a 144 tbps for system as a whole for a spatial division multiplexing approach this is probably a record this is first and only cable that i know that has leveraged this approach arelion the tier 1 backbone is exploiting c and l bands on some of its us routes to squeeze more juice out of its fibre pairs
band
band
 plus

switching karir ke migas darimana dan kemana

saya coba elaborasi sedikit ttg switching karir ke industri migas seperti yg pernah saya sebutkan dlm postingan saya sebelumnya
meski saya yakin sudah sering dibahas tapi tidak apa kita coba ulas lagi
dalam industri migas istilahistilah seperti vendor sub contractor main contractor service company dan k3s memiliki peran dan fungsi yg berbeda berikut penjelasannya

vendor
perusahaan yg menyediakan barang atau produk seperti peralatan material suku cadang maupun service yg dibutuhkan dalam kegiatan operasional migas ada vendor yg menyediakan jasa konstruksi ada juga yg menyediakan jasa non konstruksi saya pernah bekerja di perusahaan vendor konstruksi yg bergerak pada bidang heat exchangers manufaktur

sub contractor
perusahaan yg ditunjuk oleh kontraktor utama untuk melaksanakan sebagian pekerjaan tertentu dalam proyek migas
biasanya subkontraktor ini dipekerjakan oleh main kontraktor dikarenakan adanya keterbatasan source peralatan tenaga kerja expertise maupun alasan lain subkontraktor bertanggung jawab kepada kontraktor utama

di industri migas kontraktor utama adlh perusahaan yg ditunjuk oleh clientkkks dan bertanggung jawab atas keseluruhan proyek mulai dari perencanaan pengadaan konstruksi hingga instalasi dan commissioning sering juga disebut sbg perusahaan epc engineering procurement and construction

service company perusahaan jasa
perusahaan yg menyediakan jasa profesional atau teknis yang dibutuhkan dalam kegiatan eksplorasi eksploitasi dan produksi migas contohnya perusahaan survei perusahaan pengeboran atau perusahaan pemeliharaan peralatan beberapa service company yg kita kenal antara lain slb halliburton expro baker hughes weatherford dll

client kkks

contohnya pertamina petronas bp total chevron shell medco energy dll

semoga bermanfaat ya

post_text:
site visit  kattupalli yard chennai

recently i had the opportunity to visit the kattupalli yard project site in chennai where i gained handson exposure to various phases of executionconstruction revamp precommissioning and commissioning

as a civil  structural designer this visit offered deep practical insights beyond the drawing boardhighlighting onsite challenges interdisciplinary coordination and the realworld application of design

modularization  pancake method  smarter execution
we recently implemented modularization using the pancake stacking methoda technique where precast slabsmodules are stacked and lifted sequentially for efficient installation

witnessing equipment fabrication installation inspections and fluid processing firsthand deepened my appreciation for the critical role of site teams and the importance of integrating feasibility operability and performance into design

a key highlight was the strong focus on project safety from daily toolbox talks to strict permit systems and safe work practices the commitment to health safety  environment hse was evident across all teams

proud to be part of project ceresone of the worlds largest urea and ammonia plantssupporting australias fertiliser goals and global sustainability efforts

grateful toand my colleagues for this enriching experience

post_text:
installing a compressor on a gas pipeline involves several steps

1 site selection choose an appropriate location for the compressor station along the pipeline route considering factors like accessibility terrain and environmental impact

2 engineering design design the compressor station layout including the placement of the compressor unit piping valves and control systems

3 permitting obtain necessary permits and approvals from local authorities and regulatory agencies

4 procurement purchase the compressor unit piping valves instrumentation and other necessary equipment

5 construction build the compressor station infrastructure including foundations piping electrical systems and control room

6 installation install the compressor unit connecting it to the gas pipeline and other infrastructure

7 testing and commissioning conduct tests to ensure the compressor operates as expected and commission the station for operation

8 operation and maintenance operate the compressor station monitoring performance and conducting regular maintenance to ensure reliability and efficiency

throughout the installation process its crucial to follow safety protocols environmental regulations and industry standards additionally proper training for personnel involved in operating and maintaining the compressor station is essential

post_text:
draghis recipe for europe 
317 pages summed up in 10 bullet points 

 europe do something

thats how mario draghi ended his speech to the european parliament on february 19 2025 a clear call for urgent coordinated action to close the competitiveness gap between the eu and the worlds big players like the us and china

he pushed for deep reforms in energy innovation digital infrastructure and governance because europe simply cant afford to fall behind

in september 2024 he also released a full report on the future of european competitiveness i read all of it heres what matters

 the report in 10 takeaways

1 innovation under pressure
europe is behind in tech we need more rd and euwide clusters time for a madeineurope silicon valley
2 from ideas to market
too many founders leave a unitary patent and lighter regulations could turn ideas into unicorns
3 one digital market
no more 27 different rules just one framework for cloud ai and data
4 green deal 20
we need renewables without killing industry offshore wind and hydrogen should lead the way
5 facing china
chinese evs yes to targeted tariffs but europe needs its own gigafactories
6 energy without chaos
no more russian gas time for joint lng purchases and longterm contracts
7 european defense
twelve different tanks shared standards and joint procurement are the answer
8 funding innovation
a real capital markets union could direct european savings toward new tech and startups
9 faster decisions
nineteen months for one law thats too long strategic decisions must be made by majority vote
 skills for the future
ai and robotics need continuous training and global talent europe cant afford a digital divide

 source the future of european competitiveness european commission 2024

 share this if you believe europe should lead not follow
im building a project to hyperconnect the entire european innovation ecosystem

if youre a corporate accelerator or investor and want to be part of it get in touch

followif you believe open innovation starts from how we think not just what we build

post_text:
many thanks to our norwegian colleagues for the kind hospitality and the efforts to host the igf this year this has been the largest un event ever organised in norway and im genuinely impressed by the level of professionalism the same aplies to the igf secretariat  very well done

the finnish  delegation was this year led by undersecretary of state for international trade jarno syrjl along along with a delegation of colleagues from the ministry for foreign affairs over 30 finns representing various sectors of the society took part the igf which is exceptional in terms of country representation

our focus was especially on resilience of critical digital infrastructure data governance and the wsis20 review in addition we engaged in numerous bilateral meetings with partners and other stakeholders it was very useful to engage in discussions on data centers with our norwegian counterparts who have extensive first hand experience and practical knowhow on this topic

the internet is the foundation of our modern societies rightly summarised the prime minister of norway jonas gahr stre in his opening remarks good to see that the resilience of our critical digital infrastructure especially undersea telecommunication cables was also duly noted in the program

post_text:
ending network outages things you should know about the committee set up to tackle fiber cuts during road construction and rehabilitation activities

fiber networks are the backbone of nigerias digital economy they enable the seamless delivery of both fixed and mobile broadband services which are essential for nationwide connectivity economic growth and technological innovation

in 2024 there were over 50000 fiber cut incidents across the country with an estimated 30000 attributed to federal and state road construction activities these cuts have led to some of the most significant network outages the country has experiencedfor example the mtn nationwide outage in february 2024

one major reason for the increasing number of fiber cuts during road construction is the lack of an efficient coordination mechanism between road construction companies and fiber infrastructure operators

to address this persistent issue of fiber optic cuts and damage caused by road construction and rehabilitation activities the federal ministry of works and thehave established a joint standing committee on the protection of fiber optic cables

this committee which comprises key staff from both ministries and the ncc is tasked with establishing and maintaining clear communication and coordination channels between the ministries and theto limit and prevent damage to telecommunication fiber optic cables during road construction or rehabilitation activities

the committee is expected to establish protocols to reduce damage to deployed fiber optic cables caused by road construction maintenance activities and vandalism it will serve as a coordinating body for all issues related to the protection of fiber optic cablesbefore during and after road construction or maintenance activities

the committee will meet regularly to discuss identified problems agree on industrywide solutions establish standard engagement processes and procedures and share monthly performance reports

with this committee in place we expect an immediate communication mechanism between construction companies and the telecommunication industry

going forward the ministry of works will ensure that the placement of fiber cables is considered during the planning design and construction of the countrys road networks including provisions for ducts during construction

the committee will work closely with all federal controllers of works fcw to prioritize the protection of fiber cables during the planning and implementation stages of road projects across the country while coordinating with telecom operators on both ongoing and future projects

in the coming months the autoridad martima de panam amp plans to resume development of a multipurpose pier focused on serving the auxiliary maritime industry ima this project has been a constant demand from the sector and although a concession had previously been granted at amador the project never materialized

during the panama maritime chamber boards swearingin alexander de gracia deputy administrator of the amp said that the ima dock is tied up in a legal process but they expect it to be resolved soon so development can move forward

the project for the auxiliary maritime industry officially launched in mid2016 through public act no 2016203008lv005240 a best value tender posted on panama compra amps tender called for a comprehensive package feasibility study design plan approvals environmental impact study construction and maintenance of the new terminal the reference budget was set at 56 million

post_text:
installation and commissioning of cathodic protection transformer riyadh airport 

a cathodic protection transformer is a part of a cathodic protection rectifier unit cpru used in impressed current cathodic protection iccp systems it provides galvanic isolation and voltage transformation for supplying dc current to buried or submerged metal structures like pipelines tanks offshore platforms to protect them from corrosion

purpose of cp transformer

to step down high ac voltage typically 400v or 11kv to a suitable low ac voltage typically 50100v

to isolate the ac power source from the cathodic protection circuit

to supply the ac input voltage to rectifiers which convert it to dc output for corrosion protection

working principle

1 ac voltage input

2 the transformer reduces the voltage to the required level eg 50v 63v 75v ac

3 galvanic isolation it isolates the primary grid side and secondary rectifier side to prevent electrical faults from propagating

4 rectifier section the steppeddown ac is passed through a rectifier thyristorcontrolled or diodecontrolled to convert it into dc

5 dc output to structure the dc current is fed to the anodes positive terminal and the structure pipelinetank is connected to the negative terminal to suppress corrosion reactions

types of cp transformers

oilimmersed cp transformer
drytype cp transformer
transformerrectifier units tru combined transformer and rectifier in one assembly
constant voltagecurrent type transformer maintains constant voltage or current output as per protection requirements

main components of cathodic protection transformerrectifier unit

1 primary ac input terminal

2 transformer stepdown isolation

3 rectifier diodes or scr thyristors

4 metering panel voltmeter ammeter

5 control panel automanual mode

6 protection circuit breakers  fuses

7 cooling system airoilcooled

8 output dc terminal anode  structure 

applications of cp transformers

underground pipelines oil gas water pipelines
storage tanks aboveground  underground tanks
offshore structures oil rigs marine platforms
ship hulls marine vessel hull protection
bridges  piers reinforced concrete structures exposed to saltwater

testing of cp transformer

1 insulation resistance test megger

2 transformer ratio test ttr

3 winding resistance test

4 polarity  phasing check

5 no load current test

advantages of using cp transformer

controlled dc supply enables accurate control of protective dc current
isolation prevents high voltage faults from reaching protected structures
flexibility adjustable voltagecurrent settings allow tuning protection levels
reliability rugged design for harsh environmental conditions

typical ratings

primary voltage 400v  11kv  33kv
secondary voltage 50v  63v  75v
rated output current 10a 25a 50a up to 300a dc
frequency 50hz  60hz
cooling onan  an

post_text:
i recently completed a technical field exposure at gupco  gulf of suez petroleum where i gained handson insight into oilfield operations heres a breakdown of the key areas we explored

offshoretoonshore production flow

observed how fluids are gathered from satellite offshore wells and transferred via subsea pipelines to central platforms after initial separation hydrocarbons are sent through trunk lines to onshore facilities for final processing

gas lift systems

studied the use of gas lift in offshore wells learned how gas is injected to assist production and how satellite platforms are used to support remote operations

wireline operations

focused on gas lift mandrels especially side pocket mandrels used in servicing and intervention tasks

slickline bottom hole assembly bha

explored slickline tools used for running and pulling devices inside well tubing

pss workshop

visited the production support services department observed equipment testing tool maintenance and quality control procedures

drilling and casing

gained exposure to drilling rig components and casing strings with a focus on design and installation across well sections

saqqara processing station

concluded with a visit to the saqqara oil  gas processing station where we saw separation treatment and metering before export

this experience deepened my technical knowledge and gave me a clearer picture of realworld petroleum operations

grateful to the gupco team for their support and the opportunity

post_text:
summer internship with gupco  gulf of suez petroleum 
as part of our summer internship we had the privilege to gain realworld exposure across multiple vital areas in the oil  gas industryfrom offshore production to onshore processing and support services

 my experience so far has included

 drilling equipment  casing
we were introduced to the main components of drilling operations including an indepth look at casing strings we learned how these are designed and installed across different well depths to ensure safety and well integrity during production

 field production overview
we explored how offshore production starts from satellite platforms with hydrocarbons being collected and transferred via subsea pipelines to central processing hubs from there they are transported to onshore facilities for final separation and treatment

 gas lift mechanism
we studied the gas lift system applied in gupcos operations understanding how injected gas helps lift fluids to the surface especially in deep and complex wells we also examined the use of satellite platforms to support operations in remote offshore locations

 wireline operations
we gained insight into wireline services and the functionality of equipment like the side pocket mandrel which plays a key role in gas lift completions and routine well interventions

 slickline bottom hole assembly bha
we examined slickline tools and their applications in downhole operations such as installing or removing flow control devices inside the production tubing

 saqqara processing station visit
our field visit to the saqqara station gave us a firsthand view of the separation treatment and metering processes that hydrocarbons undergo before being transported for refining or export

 production support services pss workshop
we concluded with a technical tour of the pss department where we observed quality control activities like equipment testing maintenance routines and diagnostic proceduresessential steps to ensure operational reliability

a huge thank you to gupco  gulf of suez petroleum for this outstanding opportunity and for allowing us to bridge the gap between academic knowledge and field application
